name: Beata Mazurek (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Can we blame the Hungarians for being one of the first countries in Europe to take decisive steps in the fight against coronavirus? Since April 10, the Hungarian Government has begun introducing legislation aimed at limiting the impact of the coronavirus pandemic on the national economy and labour market. Thus, for example, special economic zones, where there are investments most important for the national economy, were excluded from the board of local governments and subordinated to the state administration with the acquisition of paid taxes. These decisions were preceded by the introduction on 30th March of decrees suspending certain legal acts prohibiting supplementary elections and referendums, increasing penalties for breaching a quarantine order or disseminating false information about a pandemic.  The Hungarian government's actions enabled production to resume as early as April by the largest production plants, m.in. by Audi, Mercedes, Opel and Suzuki factories. Thanks to swift and firm government action, not only has the size of the economy's losses been reduced and stopped, but the number of infected in Hungary remains lower than, for example, the Czech Republic or Austria (five times smaller).  These figures show that the decisions taken by Victor Orban's government, which effectively protects its country and its citizens from a raging pandemic, are correct.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. "No one needs to be convinced that Orban cannot be stopped by courtesy. The Hungarian Prime Minister has repeatedly pretended to be a cultured politician in Europe, and then at home, behind your back, he scolds the European Union, European values and does everything he can to turn Hungary into a dictatorship. Orban only understands by strength. His policy is motivated by money to steal as much as possible, and he is proving it every day during the epidemic, even under the Empowerment Act. He brings together regulations that have nothing to do with the epidemic, but are capable of enriching his cronies and further destroying democratic values.  We must stop persueses each other that, in a debate like this, we lament that Orban is going against everything we value. It just has to be stopped. Not after months, not with all sorts of ultimatums, but immediately.  The Hungarian Prime Minister's theft-based policy could simply be stopped. It should be excluded from the allocation of EU funds. That's what Orban would understand. Nothing else. If you really care about our common values, let us not put it on any further note: let us tie payments to the rule of law. That is what the Hungarians expect, because it is in our interest, in the interest of all Europeans.

name: Kati Piri (S&D)
text: in writing. – Arresting people for giving their opinion. Blocking the Istanbul Convention for ‘promoting gender ideology’. Banning legal gender recognition for transgender people. These are some examples of measures taken since Hungary declared an indefinite state of emergency under the guise of combatting the Covid-19 pandemic. None of these decisions prevent the virus from spreading. All they prevent is people from being themselves, being protected and speaking their minds. Hungary is not a democracy anymore. In the past ten years, we saw how an EU member state put an end to its rule of law. We just stood by and watched. Even after the latest developments, the EU is not able to take action. In a statement calling for proportionate crisis measures, the Commission President managed not to mention the country it was all about: Hungary. Still, there is no infringement procedure and no progress in the Article 7 procedure. How many more warnings, letters and expressed concerns do we need? Let this ‘state of emergency’ finally be the reason to take real action. The longer we wait, the higher the chance we miss our last opportunity to make a difference for the Hungarian people.

name: Sándor Rónai (S&D)
text: Writing. – This is not the first time that we have had to discuss the activities of the Hungarian Government in this House. There's been a lot of times in 10 years. We need to talk about it now with the Empowerment Act. It's a law that gave the government full power, citing the epidemic situation. Everyone sees orban's rampage, even though they try to make everyone think that there is nothing wrong with the rule of law in Hungary. But there is, allow me to list a few examples of so-called disease measures. The government has deprived municipalities of revenue, which has caused serious problems in many places. Many municipalities are preparing for redundancies because they simply cannot manage their wages. There are, for example, sports subsidies. It is impossible to understand that while they are delivering something to people who have lost their jobs, billions have been spent on stadiums and the construction of swimming pools. During the epidemic, the status of thousands of people as public servants was also abolished. And, of course, during the emergency, it was important to drill down on the Istanbul Convention of the governing coalition. Tell me, what does these measures have to do with disease control? Nothing. The more it has to do with the expansion of government power, the further trampling of the rule of law.

name: Isabel Santos (S&D)
text: in writing. – The debate on violations of the rule of law in Hungary has become a recurring one within the European Parliament over the last almost 10 years. The Covid19 outbreak only exacerbated the crisis of democracy in Hungary. We have been witnessing the purest and most blatant autocratic drift. Under the declaration of a state of emergency, Mr Orbán began to rule by decree, without parliamentary scrutiny, indefinitely and freedom of the press is increasingly restricted on the pretext of the need to combat disinformation. The discrimination of transsexuals is taken to the extreme outrageous, taking advantage of the silence of quarantine time. A long list of episodes that is growing in the face of hollow words and the inaction of the Commission, the Council and the EPP - the political family of FIDEZ. We can't continue to be complacent with autocrats. It's time to act with courage and determination. The lack of effectiveness in defending its core values threatens to ruin the EU's credibility. It is imperative that a mechanism for the protection of democracy and the rule of law be taken, based on conditionality of their respect for access to financial transfers from the EU budget.

name: Андрей Слабаков  (ECR)
text: in writing. – Again, we are engaged in a debate devoid of meaning. Now is the time for quick and meaningful action. We need to discuss concrete measures that will save lives and rebuild the economy. Instead, you have decided to clean up your old accounts with Hungary and Orban. You oppose so-called tyranny, but you actually use your position to punish those Member States that refuse to join your dream of Empire Europe and its "new values and morals."  Why else are we hearing about the Istanbul Convention today? It has nothing to do with the current crisis or with emergency measures in Hungary. Colleagues, you're using real problems again to force left-wing ideas. You don't care about civil rights and freedoms, just your political goals. Where are the accusations against the Socialist government in Spain and their disinformation campaign? Why are you jumping only against Hungarian measures to combat fake news? So the whole EU is against disinformation, isn't it?  It is hypocritical, colleagues, to hide behind false concerns about the constitutional rights of Hungarians, but not to pay attention to Conte's attempts to circumvent the Italian Constitution. Deal with the real problems in the EU. Let's go back to meaningful and socially useful activity.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. – The actions of governments and their increased powers, at a time when the corona crisis is being combated, must not be abused by governments. This is in no EU country, including Hungary. It is essential that the EU monitors any attempt by a Member State to restrict citizens' freedom and their fundamental rights. Especially in countries where there have long been warning signs of non-compliance with democratic rules. Parliament must have the power to put an end to the state of emergency. International agreements continue to apply. Powers should have clear mannequins and not be deliberately defined for the widest possible space of manoeuvre for the use of power. I consider the benevolent and spontaneous criminalisation of citizens or the journalistic community to be particularly dangerous, with no possibility of adequately defending themselves at a particular time.

name: József Szájer (PPE)
text: in writing. – While the Parliament has still failed to restore its legitimate functioning, it is now arbitrarily extending the scope of the procedures for which it is supposed to have a mandate. The current functioning of the European Parliament is based on a Bureau decision with limited scope to urgency procedures. Deviation from the order of ordinary plenary sessions is also only possible on the grounds of urgency, ensuring the possibility for the President to convene extraordinary sessions of the Parliament. Commission proposals on the pandemic, discharge and other decisions related to the budgetary power of the Parliament do require an urgency procedure. It should be noted however that the extension of the scope of the urgency procedures beyond these is strictly unlawful and would be even if, provided, but not allowed, the Bureau decision on the current functioning and the electronic voting system gave a legitimate mandate for the Parliament to operate. Fisheries Partnership Agreement, dactyloscopic data exchange in the United Kingdom, just to name a few examples, do not meet the criteria of the urgency procedure hence does not fall within the scope of the operation allegedly provided for by the Bureau decision allowing the electronic voting system.

name: Hermann Tertsch (ECR)
text: in writing. – It was regrettable to hear MEPs launch accusations and defamations against Hungary today. Viktor Orbán has more than two-thirds parliamentary support – 137 out of 190 – which has given him special powers for an effective fight against the pandemic, which is being a success.  Added sarcasm is to hear these accusations from the mouth of a Spanish socialist. A member of Pedro Sánchez's PSOE, allied with Podemos's communists, who trampl on every democratic guarantee, monitor, threaten and pursue critical opinions and use the police for political intimidation. With a rachytic minority achieved with deception, he has to rule with separatists, coupists and philistists. While Spain suffers the worst death per capita in the world, with 40,000 already dead, partly hidden by the government. And 50,000 infected toilets, the result of failure and incompetence. The social-communist government, with links to dictatorships in Venezuela and Cuba and ties to The Colombian drug trafficking terrorist organization FARC, is dismantling democracy in Spain and building a cage.  Compare Hungary and Spain today, both in democratic freedoms and in the fight against the coronavirus, and you will see that where the Commission has to be alarmed is not in Budapest, it is in Madrid.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. – As a Hungarian MEMBER and a patriot, I am infinitely sad that the policies of the Hungarian Government are once again on the agenda. Hungary deserves more than that. Let's look at reality. The MSZP has launched the "Dictatorship Monitor" application on its online platform, which takes a look at the excesses that Fidesz is carrying out in hiding behind the protection against the coronavirus. There's plenty of it. In recent days, for example, "scaremongering" has caused more people to be arrested by police for criticising the government's handling of the epidemic on their social media pages.  Fidesz's immorality is also demonstrated by the way it uses the epidemic to take down opposition mayors: a proposal was recently submitted, citing the emergency, which takes tax revenues and powers from the government-selected (opposition) municipalities and gives it to the Fidesz-led county governments. It is ignominious that even this epidemic situation is being used by the Hungarian Government for political vengeance and looting.  Now, when we also decide on the next seven-year budget, the question must arise: how can an anti-EU Government of the Member States be sanctioned without any harm to the country or its citizens. I propose that we make the payment of EU funds for accession to the European Public Prosecutor's Office. Until Orban is willing to do so, he cannot decide on the allocation of European funds. Independent decision-makers in Brussels will judge the proposals. Stop fattening your oligarchs and stealth dictatorship with EU funds.

name: Henna Virkkunen (PPE)
text: Written. "The coronavirus pandemic puts all European societies in a situation where the risks of breaking the principles of the rule of law and democracy are greater than usual. Societies in which these principles have already been wiped off the floor in the past are in danger of falling deeper and deeper into a spiral of authoritarianism. When you go deep enough in such a spiral, it is very difficult to get out of there anymore. Hungary is now very close to this border and its democracy is close to disintegration. As for Hungary, my concern relates not only to state of emergency legislation, but to the longer development of the country. In Hungary, the Orbán Government has systematically reduced the room for manoeuvre of the media, civil society and science, concentrating power on itself in a way that does not follow the rules of the game of a democratic society. The situation in Hungary has been woken up far too late in Europe. Those following the rule of law developments in different countries have been warning of developments in Hungary since the early 2010s, when Fidesz was planning the first major changes to its country's institutional structure. The situation has only been taken seriously when major damage has already been done. It is clear that, at the latest, all the measures that have previously been considered too difficult must be fully implemented. The Article 7 procedure must be speeded up and Hungary must be put in a situation where its right to vote in the Council is under threat. More importantly, the EU's money taps will be cut. They are the lifeline of Viktor Orbán, with which he builds his own central capitalism, in which the victors are those in power and those close to them.

name: Jadwiga Wiśniewska (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – It is really incomprehensible why, during the pandemic, we are dealing with the rule of law in Hungary, namely its alleged violation by extraordinary measures introduced, as in many other Member States, to effectively combat the pandemic. In addition, the form in which this debate is conducted does not allow the Hungarian Government to put forward arguments in its defence. This is incompatible with the principle of a fair trial, which is also a fundamental principle of the rule of law. If the President of the EP had allowed a representative of the Hungarian Government to speak, we would have learned that the Emergency Act does not give the government unlimited powers. They end at the end of the pandemic or even earlier if parliament so decides. The European Commission is aware of this and therefore does not initiate infringement proceedings. Today's debate is further evidence of the application of double standards in the EU.

name: Presidente. –
text: I have the honour to introduce the next item on the agenda, nothing less than the statements by the Council and the Commission on the 70th anniversary of the Schuman Declaration (2020/2642(RSP)). As you all know, the traditional catch-the-eye or 'blue card' procedures are not foreseen for this debate.

name: Nikolina Brnjac
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, we are celebrating the 70th anniversary of the Schuman Declaration in truly unprecedented and challenging circumstances. Today, we are faced with heart—breaking numbers: more than 100 000 people have died in the European Union. Let me from the outset express my sympathy with those who have lost their loved ones and my gratitude to the essential workers in hospitals and care homes, but also in shops, transportation and public services. Moreover, millions of citizens have faced unprecedented restrictions aimed at containing the spread of the virus. The pandemic is putting our societies under serious strain. But the crisis has shown that, with the right synergy and close cooperation between Member States and EU institutions in the spirit of the Schuman Declaration, we can provide efficient and effective solutions. The Commission and the ECB took exceptional steps. The Parliament and the Council adopted, without delay, emergency packages of legislation. The European Council has given overall direction. I will not go into details on the EU response. Let me just say that work continues with a sense of urgency and a determination. As Prime Minister Plenković said on Saturday, from the start of our Presidency, we have been dealing with complex and important issues for the future of Europe: from ensuring an orderly Brexit and agreeing on a mandate for negotiation with the United Kingdom to negotiation of the Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) package, discussions about the Green Deal and with a strong emphasis on enlargement policy and our strategic relations with the Western Balkans. The negotiations on the MFF for the period 2021—2027 will now intensify with a new approach in the changed circumstances. Of course, the COVID—19 pandemic poses an unprecedented and unexpected challenge for all of us, as well as unprecedented administrative and logistical challenges for our Presidency. We’ve had to react quickly and find solutions to be able to ensure continuity of decision—making and make sure that the Union can act. Within the Council, we have ensured effective discussions and rapid agreements on a number of European regulations and guidelines for more flexible use of European funds, easier procurement and production of medical equipment, and assuring the flow of goods across borders as well as the transport corridors. In addition, we have facilitated the repatriation of all European citizens from third countries, enabled coordinated monitoring of the development of the epidemiological situation and facilitated the decisions on reducing restrictions at a national level, which should also lead to a revival of tourism and business activities. Our response to the crisis is comprehensive and strong in order to preserve jobs, entrepreneurship and ensure a rapid and effective recovery while strengthening the solidarity and resilience of all Member States and our neighbours. Furthermore, I would like to highlight our work on enlargement; first with the new methodology, then with the Council decision to open negotiations with Albania and North Macedonia. I would also like to highlight the recent EU—Western Balkans Zagreb Summit and the adoption of the Zagreb Declaration, which reaffirms and consolidates a clear European perspective and future of our Western Balkan partners. It is a situation where the European Union is facing the greatest challenges since the World War 2. The Conference on the Future of Europe can serve as an important framework for reflection, open debate and a vision of our common European future in a dialogue between all Member States, European institutions and with full involvement of our citizens and other stakeholders. The Presidency will spare no efforts in working to reach a consensus in the Council as soon as possible and in securing an agreement with the other European institutions on the timing and manner of launching this conference, which is important for the long—term future of Europe. ‘World peace cannot be safeguarded without the making of creative efforts proportionate to the dangers which threaten it’, said Robert Schuman in the opening words of his Declaration 70 years ago. Today, the context is obviously different, but the dangers are no less real and deserve creative efforts proportionate to them. The motto of the Croatian Presidency: ‘a strong Europe in a world of challenges’ applies today even more than on the first day of our Presidency. I have travelled from Zagreb to this plenary for almost 10 hours to underline our Presidency’s determination to continue working closely with the European Parliament. Indeed, it is my firm belief and we remain united in solidarity, we can emerge from this crisis together.

name: Maroš Šefčovič
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, 75 years ago, the guns of the Second World War in Europe fell silent. The Nazi regime was defeated, but Europe lay in ruins. Just five years later, on 9 May 1950, Robert Schuman made a declaration that would profoundly change this continent and would put it on a path that no one could have anticipated. For me, this is a very special moment. Seventy years ago, Robert Schuman started a journey, step by step. He showed us the way and the direction. And today, here we are. Just seven days ago, at the EU—Western Balkans Summit, we laid the ground for reuniting the Western Balkans with our union, reuniting Europe’s history with its geography. Yes, today, our union faces its greatest challenge yet: a pandemic that knows no borders, a pandemic that threatens our lives and our way of life, a pandemic that has tested our union to its core. But, as so often in history, this crisis has also shown Europe’s greatest strengths: our commitment to unity, born of common values and shared history, and our solidarity with those in need. Schuman’s words resonate today more strongly than ever before: ‘it is no longer a time for vain words, but for a bold, constructive act’. The Schuman Declaration embodied the perfect balance, the delicate dance between idealism and pragmatism, without which there would be no European Union and no European solidarity as we know it today. He famously said, ‘Europe will not be made all at once according to a single plan. It will be built through concrete achievements which first create a de facto solidarity.’ This crisis has put that solidarity to the hardest of tests. In March, some even said that we would not pass these tests. But, if you look around the world today, Europe has become the beating heart of solidarity: French patients treated in German hospitals, Polish doctors and Romanian nurses working in Italy, and a huge recovery plan is in the making. The world is watching. Our European model will only mean something to the world if we show solidarity within our union’s borders, to each other, and beyond, with our partners globally.  Since the pandemic began, the European Union has been working on all fronts to contain the spread of the coronavirus, support health systems, protect and save lives, and counter the socioeconomic impacts of the pandemic, with historically unprecedented measures at both national and EU level. The Commission will directly support the healthcare systems of EU countries with EUR 3 billion from the EU budget, matched with EUR 3 billion from the Member States to fund the Emergency Support Instrument and the rescEU common stockpile of equipment. The rescEU initiative helps secure vital equipment, from ventilators to personal protective equipment, and to mobilise medical teams for assistance to the most vulnerable, including in refugee camps. The first hosting state of this stockpile is Romania.  The production of the first ventilators has started, and some 330 000 protective masks were delivered to Spain, Italy and Croatia in the past weeks. Since the beginning of the outbreak, thanks to the EU Civil Protection Mechanism and consular protection coordination, the European Union has brought home over half a million citizens stranded all over the world. Thanks to the Emergency Support Instrument, the European Union has procured another 10 million masks, the first 1.5 million of which have already been delivered to 17 Member States.  I want to thank this House for having launched the ‘Europeans Against COVID—19’ campaign. This Europe Day, the Commission and the Council joined forces with you, and we all pay tribute to those who are making history today, the everyday heroes fighting the coronavirus in our hospitals, in research labs, or by delivering personal protective equipment to those in need, because we know that coronavirus knows no borders.  Tackling this pandemic is a global challenge and the EU is leading the global effort to develop and deploy effective diagnostics, treatments and a vaccine. Without this tool, every country in the world remains vulnerable. Countries and international organisations are joining forces to develop these tools and put the structures in place that ensure they are universally available and affordable. How wealthy a country is should not determine whether its people get to live without this virus.  That is why President von der Leyen launched an international pledging marathon on 4 May. So far, we have raised EUR 7.4 billion, and this includes a pledge of EUR 1.4 billion from the Commission. But we know that more is needed and I am confident it will come. The crisis gives us an opportunity to lead by example and to reach for our highest aspirations, even when, in the short term, it might be easier to give in to our lowest instincts.  We will be remembered tomorrow for how we act today. Therefore, this crisis forces us to reflect. The pandemic will have a lasting effect, not just on the global system, but also on our daily lives. It is vital that on our path to recovery, we reach out, engage and listen to citizens, at European, national, regional and local level.  The Conference on the Future of Europe is an ideal forum for that and should commence as soon as conditions allow it. The Conference, as a pan—European democratic exercise, can reinforce the link between European citizens and the institutions. It can help rebuild trust and solidarity, even in the new coronavirus reality. The context might have changed, but our determination has not. We want the Conference on the Future of Europe to give citizens a greater say in shaping future EU policies, and we want this to be a joint exercise, involving the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission on an equal footing. That is also why any decision on when to launch the Conference must be a joint one taken by all three institutions. Given the circumstances, my colleague and friend, Vice—President Šuica, who is leading the Commission’s efforts on the Conference, is following this debate remotely from Croatia. She is very much looking forward to joining the debates in this House in a physical mode as soon as possible. In order to be ready for the launch of the Conference under the containment measures scenario, the Commission is exploring digital solutions to enable us to host virtual debates and dialogues. We are working on a multilingual digital platform, allowing citizens to share their results and promote interactive ways for public engagement as part of the Conference. Such a digital platform would be open to all EU institutions. But a digital solution alone cannot reach everyone and cannot compensate for the real deal: face—to—face town hall discussions and workshops across the continent, reaching people from all walks of life. To protect the health of our citizens, we need to be patient and plan accordingly, step by step. Once the Council has adopted its mandate, we will get there. I am confident that the next step, the joint declaration by the Parliament, the Commission and the Council, which is necessary to launch the Conference, is within reach.  A little more than 30 years ago, I was looking through the barbed wire of the infamous Iron Curtain to Austria. This fence was just two kilometres from our apartment and I passed it every single day. I could see the people, the houses and the lights on the other side of the Danube, but I was told by my father that I would never be able to cross the border. Therefore, for me, the Schuman Declaration celebration is also a celebration of the European dream and freedom. I am sure that Robert Schuman would be proud today of how much we have accomplished. But I am also convinced that he would push us higher and further. Therefore, let’s respond to his inspiration by building an even fairer, greener, freer and stronger Europe. (Applause)

name: Esteban González Pons
text: PPE Group. – Mr President, the European Union is the political heritage left to us by our parents' generation. Our parents understood that either Europe was built, or dictatorship and war would return. Europe or war. The idea is so simple that Robert Schuman only needed 868 words to explain it. And it should be remembered today because, like a hundred years ago, nationalism has once again taken root in the hearts of Europeans. Nationalism is the coronavirus that infects our politics.  It is nationalist to give twenty-seven different national responses to a single pandemic. It is nationalist not to approve the criteria by which they are infected, killed or cured to have a better national position in the ranking of countries. It is nationalist to close borders without coordination. It is nationalist to insolidate with masks, medicines, hospital places or financial aid, It is nationalist to reach the European Council with the intention of taking as much money as possible. It is nationalist to value national successes for how long it took me to my country and not how much we get all the countries together. It is nationalist that for the recovery plan no prime minister is contemplating the European economy as a whole.  Aren't there any more European leaders left in Europe? Let's stop facing north and south and east and west just to get votes in our respective countries. If we sow tares among Europeans, we will collect discord among Europeans. To be a Europeanist is to explain to the north and south, to the east and west. We Europeanists understand each other, we don't face each other.  Let us once and for all share our national selfishness, our filias and our phobias. Let us abandon the "I" and the "mine" to think of the "we" and "ours". History has shown that we can move forward together without giving up our national identities. In the face of the selfish discourse of nationalism, we defend the generosity of European patriotism and the value of peace.

name: Iratxe García Pérez
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr President, before I take the floor on this point I would like to be able to reply ⸺as I have not been able to do so, in the case of no blue card⸺ to Mr Gunnar Beck, of the previous debate, who said that Members who were not here are on holiday. Mr. Beck, make no mistake. I think I speak for all of them: if they're not here, it's not on a whim. They are saving lives, they are meeting the standards set by different national governments. I understand that the far right is not very used to this, but really Members who are not here do so in a responsible way, because they take into account that it is necessary to stop this virus among all. This May 9th, the Schuman Declaration was seventy years old. With this declaration and from the ashes of World War II the path of peace, freedom and solidarity of the European Union that we know today began. In these seventy years, Europe has given peace and prosperity to its citizens and has grown to twenty-seven countries. Despite the pitfalls that have appeared on this journey, the Union has always been strengthened, and today we can proudly vindicate our motto of 'United in Diversity'. In building the common European project, the Socialists and Democrats are proud of our contribution so that the Union was not just a common market. It was with Jacques Delors, in 1989, that the social dimension was introduced with the adoption of the Charter of Fundamental Social Rights of Workers, and it has been our goal, ever since, to build a community and not just a market. And it will continue to be.  Unfortunately, this year we celebrate a different May 9th, with the mourning for those who have died from this crisis and coming out of our lockdowns in the face of a future full of uncertainties.  As president of the Group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats, but also as a European citizen, I am convinced that we will come out of this crisis stronger. On this anniversary, our political family wants to demand a courageous way out of this crisis, and we really need the unity of all European Democrats.  Before the crisis, the Union had set up a European conference to rethink its future, and now we must also include recovery.  Let it be the conference for the recovery and the future of Europe, because it will be visible. And it will be important for this discussion to set political priorities by listening to citizenship, civil society; that this conference does not stay exclusively in the Brussels bubble, that we can open up and listen to those who have things to say to us.  Ladies and gentlemen, the European project has always been a project for the future and has not succumbed to pessimism. As Jean Monnet thought, every crisis is an opportunity to take a step forward. On this seventyth anniversary, let us turn this crisis into an opportunity ⸺with the memory of those who are not⸺ to renew the European Union by making it stronger, fairer and more supportive.

name: Pascal Durand
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. Mr President, everyone today applauds the visionary genius of the fathers of Europe, the Schuman, Monnet, Adenauer, Spinelli. At the risk of disappointing, I would prefer to raise their intelligence and pragmatism. They understood at the time that we would not be able to rebuild the necessary Europe without enshrining it in cooperation, peace, democracy and solidarity. Without solidarity between peoples and between states, they said, there will be no sustainable future for Europe. So, seventy years later, where are we? We are not starting from scratch, we have managed to build an extremely powerful economy, a market, free movement for people and goods. We have succeeded in securing democracy and integrating the countries that were on the other side of the wall. This is a step forward that we cannot deny. But that is not enough, it is no longer enough. We need to become a great political power. We need to consolidate our democracy. For this, we need, as you have reminded us, Mr 'Ef-ovi', of course, we need to succeed in this conference for the future of Europe. We need to move our democracy with citizens. We also need to put an end to the stupid rule of unanimity that blocks any evolution. We need to speak with one voice. We need models that go beyond the interests of each member country to bring a general European interest. Yes, we must live up to the challenges of the twenty-first century, define the new rules of a community based on cooperation, on trade and new rules, on fair exchange, on peace, the environment and social. I must say that without this ability to build, without this ability to cooperate, without getting out of this tax competition that enriches some and impoverishes others, we will not succeed. I would just like to end by recalling a sentence from a French poet. Jacques Prévert said that we recognize happiness by the noise he makes when we leave us. Today I express the wish that tomorrow we do not have to hear the sound of democracy, peace and justice leaving us.

name: Jörg Meuthen
text: On behalf of the ID Group, I would like to make a i-see of the Mr President, I would like to thank the Today we are talking about the Schuman Plan, which is celebrating its 70th anniversary. This plan laid the foundations for what we now call the European Union. It was a good plan with historical implications. It marked the beginning of the german-French reconciliation, the beginning of the European peace project, which has continued to this day. He provided for peace and prosperity through economic cooperation. That was wise, and it worked – to this day. For decades, this has become the EU's internal market today.  So far, so good, so successful. At that time, there was no provision for the abolition of national sovereignty. There were no plans to dissolve France, Germany and other states in an art entity called the United States of Europe. That would not have been wise, and it is not today. Nevertheless, armies of today's politicians are also pursuing this project in this House, thereby producing the stark opposite of what Schuman intends: divergence instead of convergence, aggression instead of peace, disintegration instead of cooperation. They just don't understand the chaos they're wreating on because they want much more than the Schuman plan, in a wise restriction on economic cooperation, we're going to lose everything in the end. This is a historic tragedy for the nations of Europe.

name: Ska Keller
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, the success of the Schuman Declaration is certainly undoubtable. Lasting peace on a warring continent is a paramount achievement. But still, our Union has come even further, has been even more successful by working together. We expanded to overcome big parts of the Iron Curtain division and integrated in an ever closer Union to the benefit of the people living within. Crises, like the one we are crossing today, prove how much we have come to take for granted all the achievements of our Union. Just think about the freedom of movement.  However, it is hardly the time to pat ourselves on the back. The world today is very different from that of Schuman. We have digitalisation, globalisation, a growing nationalism, climate change. All those have fundamentally affected our realities, and the COVID-19 crisis today leaves millions without jobs, a stable income or future perspectives.  Today, our Union needs an immense leap forward. Europe needs again a Schuman-type future-proof solution oriented action. So what can this leap forward be? First of all, it should be a people and planet centred recovery from the multiple crises that Europe is currently facing – the social inequalities, the climate and biodiversity crises, the public health crisis. It is high time we used all the instruments at our disposal to create the most ambitious social, economic and environmental transformation the world has ever seen, and this must ensure that no one is left behind.  Secondly, this leap forward must re-anchor our European Union in the respect of citizens’ rights, democracy and fundamental rights, because these have too often been sidelined in recent years.  Thirdly, a strong and future-proofed Union must also look beyond its immediate borders. Our Union must always offer shelter to those seeking protection. It must be open to countries that want to join and meet our rules.  We are living through challenging times for our Union. We must now prove that we can live up to those challenges. Seventy years from now, history will judge whether we have passed the test.

name: Derk Jan Eppink
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. Mr President, 70 years after the Schuman declaration, Europe is once again at a crossroads. Which way are we going? There are actually two sides. One side is the formation of a kind of EU state, for which most of this Parliament is in favour, with a European government, European taxes, a European army and European debt. The great advocate of this idea is Mr Verhofstadt, who unfortunately is not here now, but we found a booklet of his from the past, at least ten years ago, in which he advocates a European empire. He's talking about a New Age of Empires. You have a Russian empire, a Chinese empire, an American empire, and now you have to add a European empire, a European Empire. Well, we, the European Conservatives and Reformists, want to go in a different direction, namely a community of sovereign European states, with a common market for trade and industry, for example. No centralization like this, no bureaucracy. We do want flexibility and let each country decide for itself which currency it wants. We also want respect for the constitutions of the various countries and a modest budget for emergency aid. That is why, in my final seconds, I say speaking time: let the citizens decide what they want. Let them decide that in a referendum. What do they want? Mr Verhofstadt's European empire or our community of European states?

name: Manon Aubry
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the European Union is always ready to romanticize its own history, but rarely to learn from it. Taking seriously the exercise of memory that is proposed to us today would, however, allow us to learn from past policies in the face of exceptional circumstances. To cope with crises, states often taxed the wealthy: a tax on war-profit enterprises in France in 1916, an exceptional contribution from the great fortunes in 1945 in Germany.  The current level of inequality and fiscal injustice is not the natural course of events. As we now face one of the worst crises in our history, how can we not put those who continue to get disproportionately rich back? Today, those who benefit from coronavirus are called Amazon, Netflix, Carrefour or Sanofi. Let us tax their exceptional profits rather than making the peoples of Europe pay for the crisis. History also shows us that paying down an unsustainable debt cannot be the horizon of a people. This is why more than half of the war debt of the Federal Republic of Germany was erased in 1953. Greece should have received the same treatment from the European Union. Corona-debt is neither legitimate nor repayable. Organising its pooling and cancellation via the European Central Bank is the only viable solution, except to impose unprecedented austerity on all European peoples. Faced with coronavirus and the climate challenge, European heads of state and institutions have a unique responsibility: not to miss out on history and finally give meaning to the word solidarity.

name: Jeroen Lenaers (PPE).
text: Mr President, 70 years ago in Paris, Robert Schuman launched the construction of a united Europe on the basis of concrete achievements in mutual solidarity. And concrete achievements came. We got the chance to cross the border and work, live, do business there. Freedoms that we took for granted a few months ago, but which are suddenly under pressure again today. Borders were locked all over Europe. In my own village, the passage is suddenly being barred by meter-high fences and containers between the Netherlands and Belgium. This is unnecessary and it puts the axe at the root of our cooperation and with it our prosperity. More coordination is needed, especially at this stage. It is inconceivable that we can develop effective exit strategies if we do not cooperate more intensively with each other. So: look out and over borders. Also for our border entrepreneurs, because they, like many other entrepreneurs, are hit hard in this crisis. For example, an entrepreneur who has a business in the Netherlands but lives in Belgium or Germany does not receive support from any country. They pay taxes and social security contributions for years, but when it comes down to it, they have nowhere to go. These people feel abandoned. They wonder where that one Europe went. I can imagine that feeling very well. 9 May should be a European holiday, but as long as there are containers on the border and border operators fall between shore and ship, there is not much to celebrate. If Robert Schuman had lived today, I think he would have shed a tear sooner.

name: Domènec Ruiz Devesa (S&D).
text: – Mr President, on this seventyth anniversary of the founding of the Union — of our project — Europe has faced the most difficult situation since 1950. The coronavirus pandemic is only the last challenge on a long list we've faced in the last ten years. From climate change to the new geopolitics, to digitization, Brexit and Trump's election in the Presidency of the United States.  It is true that Schuman said in his Declaration — and it has been remembered very much — that Europe would not be done at once, but through the creation of de facto solidarity. But he also said— and it must be said at the same time — that the ECSC was the first step for a European federation. He thus gathered the spirit of Ventotene's manifesto, a historical mission that we must complete.  Therefore, this moment is not the occasion of the small steps, but that of a great step forward. It is time to respond to the triple public, economic and institutional health crisis with three unions: health, financial and politics.

name: Gerolf Annemans (ID).
text: – Mr President, one of the main advantages of founding fathers is that they usually never contradict. So, again today, Schuman is again frequently dragged into this House to promote the expansion of the centralised unitary state. However, the COVID-19 crisis is a historic moment, as it has become the momentum of its own Member State. The Member State is the only forum with sufficient democracy. Only democracy and trust can we leave vital issues, such as the management of our national borders, health care and social security based on voluntary solidarity. Ladies and gentlemen, if you only see the future of Europe as an ever closer Union and nothing else, as is already the case in the conference, then you are missing that momentum. Europe will never be able or should be something like this. European cooperation will have to respect diversity. Otherwise, I predict you, you will tear up your Union.

name: Peter Lundgren (ECR).
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr At the same time, as we celebrate the 70th anniversary of the Schuman Declaration, we are in one of the worst crises the Union has ever experienced. At a very high price, it is now also clear that the European Union is a project which, in every crisis, is paralysed and unable to react quickly and in solidarity.  From the outset, the European project has been about the construction of a political and economic union. However, it is now clear that the Union has grown into a gigantic colossus on clay feet, sucking more and more power from the Member States.  It is time to reform this project into what it should be. It should be cooperation to promote trade and therefore also in an extension of peace. A 70-year-old declaration needs to be updated. It needs to be updated to the present and it needs to be updated to the world we are looking at now.

name: Leila Chaibi (GUE/NGL).
text: Mr President, if it is true that we are celebrating a birthday, then perhaps it is time to share the cake. Today we are celebrating the seventyth anniversary of the Schuman Declaration and there have been speeches and deeds in Europe for seventy years. In speeches, it is solidarity and in actions, it is competition and everyone for himself. It started with Robert Schuman in 1950, who explained to us that solidarity was going to be at the heart of European construction and, at the same time, set the foundations for the Europe of markets. More recently, in France, President Macron, barely elected, gave us a bombastic speech at the Sorbonne on Europe, in which he repeated the word solidarity thirteen times and, at the same time, on the recommendations of the European Commission, he began to break, break public services and break the public health service, which we see today how essential it is to solidarity. Everywhere in Europe, it is the same story and it is high time to listen to the citizens, their anger, the anger of the citizens who can no longer stand this game of dupes and who, everywhere, rightly demand their share of the pie.

name: Herbert Dorfmann (PPE).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report, which is a very good one. In which half of the last century would you have preferred to live, in the first half or in the second half? I am glad that I was born and raised in the second half of the last century, in a time of hope, not hatred and destruction.  I think the political spirit of Robert Schuman and the politician of his time played a significant part in this, my happiness. But I also want my children, who were born in the first half of this century, and myself and my generation, to continue to share in this happiness, and for us to continue to enjoy it.  Our sailing ship "European Union" has arrived at a very decisive buoy. We can continue to sail towards prosperity and towards the future. But then we need a route, we need a vision, and we need the belief that we can shape the future together. Or we can turn back on this buoy, and we can sail back into this Europe of opposition, nationalism and opportunism.  I am convinced that we need courage. When I look at these days and weeks of crisis, I have the impression that we have sometimes lost this courage and will. Any crisis – and there is no doubt that we are in it – is also an opportunity, also a political opportunity. People expect us to give concrete answers in these difficult days and weeks of the Corona crisis. And with time, with the spirit of Robert Schuman and his political contemporaries, we can give this answer. Seventy years of the Schuman Declaration are therefore a cause for celebration, but also an occasion to reflect on how we deal with the heritage of these politicians.

name: Gabriele Bischoff (S&D).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Seventy years ago, no one could have imagined what a journey this great European project, the foundation of which was laid with this Schuman Declaration, would take – because there were courageous Europeans such as Schuman, Monet and Spinelli.  And we are now at a turning point in Europe. What we urgently need is precisely this Schuman moment, as it was 70 years ago, which helps us to get out of this crisis and to set the course for an effective, strong and resilient Union. And in the spirit of the Schuman Declaration, we must now ensure that we really use this crisis as an opportunity. Let us just imagine that ten or 15 years ago we had the courage to actually reform Europe. We would not have border closures and new nationalism, no petty statehood and national solo actions, and no crisis-prone euro. That is why it is important that we now see this future conference as a new starting point for this Schuman moment. Because Europe is not built by fine phrases, but by solidarity of action.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ID).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, seventy years has not been enough to make Europe. Take the coronavirus emergency: where has the much-vaunted European solidarity gone? First you treated the Italians like stickers, then you pretended to apologize and now, that it's time to get the money out, what do you do? You want to steal that money on loan and with the ES MES: what do you call solidarity? But don't you feel a little shame? Italians need real money, such as the billions that our country pays to this Europe every year as slaves to banks and multinationals. We do not want your alms, we want our money back, all of us immediately, because we have to save the lives of millions of Italians and the lives of millions of companies. Dear European bureaucrats, Schuman, De Gasperi and Adenauer are turning in their graves in the face of your actions. You have betrayed the European dream, you are killing Europe because, if you have not yet understood it, either this Europe changes immediately or it is destined to die.

name: Ryszard Czarnecki (ECR).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I am pleased to see so many Members in this House. The Minister representing the Croatian Presidency said that she had been driving here for almost 10 hours by car. I rode almost 12 precisely to tell during this session about the great man Robbie Schuman, who, together with Alcid de Gasperi and the other founding fathers of Europe, decided to create a construction that would be a firewall for the two totalitarianism of the 20th century, on the one hand communism and, on the other hand, national socialism in Germany. In my opinion, he deserves a great deal of recognition.  Let us recall that he imagined a common Europe as an economic structure, but he also referred to Christian roots, to heritage, to tradition. We should bear this in mind and not amputate this heritage, which is part of our European history.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the Schuman Declaration, which initiated European integration, is still striking because of its ambition and pragmatism. The same ambition and the same pragmatism, Mr Šefčovič, we must have today: we cannot get lost in endless debates. It is all very well to restart the conference on the future of Europe soon, but it must not be a bridge for inconclusive chatter, we need to achieve the goal. Proud of our history and the many objectives achieved, we must get our Union back on its hands deeply in order to overcome the delays, mistakes and inability of the Union as it is today. This means no more cross-vetoes from the Member States, no more gruelling budget negotiations, finally giving the Eu ropean Union more own resources through a web tax and a tax on speculative financial transactions. No more timidity in the face of violations of the rule of law and social rights. I hope that this Parliament can be united in its fight for these objectives, because I believe that we need european federation today. If not now, when?

name: Jordan Bardella (ID).
text: Mr President, on the occasion of the seventyth anniversary of the Schuman Declaration, you are bragging about celebrating Europe with great pomp, but what Europe exactly are you talking about? Are you talking about this Europe which, in 2005, flouted the no of France and the Netherlands to the smoking European Constitution? Are you talking about this Europe of free trade agreements, the latest with Mexico, which imposed unfair international competition on our farmers? Are you talking about this Europe that has bowed to Erdogan's blackmail, watering Turkey with billions of euros out of the pockets of European taxpayers? Are you talking about this Europe that left Greece alone to protect our continent from the migration invasion? Are you talking about this Europe whose first reaction to the virus was to warn the European countries that have restored borders and whose impotence has thrown Italy into the arms of China? The Europe you are celebrating is the Trojan horse of a populicide front that will always prefer the misery of the end of the world rather than that of the corner of its street, as evidenced by your obsession with integrating Albania and Northern Macedonia, in the midst of a health crisis. The real Europe, we will build it without you and your chimeras, but with the peoples, the nations and their sovereignty that are the beating heart of it.

name: Nicola Beer (Renew).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the "Europe cannot be produced in one fell swoop, nor by a simple summary. It will be created by concrete facts that will first create a solidarity of action." This sentence by Robert Schuman on the birth of Europe has lost none of its relevance.  In the rubble of war, it was common resources, coal and steel, that created trust between the arch-enemies that laid the foundation for a common area of justice.  Schuman was a lawyer, lawyer, minister of justice. No wonder his idea of Europe was a community based on the rule of law – in which power is not above law, but the law is above power, in which not victors and the vanquished face each other, but states rally behind the unifying, but also binding, guideline of law.  Thus, conflict did not become a war, a dispute did not become bloodshed, but the search for a common interest.  This community of law is our most valuable resource. This resource must be preserved and further developed for a better Europe across all political camps.

name: Maroš Šefčovič
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank you for this very important debate. Your statements have been very clear. On one side, most of us acknowledge that we have accomplished a lot together since the Schuman Declaration and there is a lot of which we are rightly so proud of. But, at the same time, you called for more solidarity, more action and, what I would call, result—oriented policies from our Union, which, as Ms Keller has said, must be more planet- and people-centred. All of you called for the big debate with our European citizens under the Conference on the Future of Europe to take place as soon as possible. Because at a time like this we all feel that we need to listen more to the people – I would say even more than before – to include them in our decision-making and then, of course, to draw lessons about how we can fulfil their proposals, wishes and dreams in the best possible way. I think we have to remind ourselves that, when Robert Schuman made his declaration for this bold and constructive action in 1950, his words did not fall on deaf ears. There was immediate follow-up. Less than one year later, the founding six countries would go on to sign the Treaty of Paris, establishing what would later become the European Union. This is how they materialised his call for peace in Europe and for legal protection against the different views of those who were more powerful at that moment, as Ms Beer has just reminded us. It was done in a big rush and what is often overlooked is the fact that, with the negotiations being done so quickly, the piece of paper that ministers signed was, in fact, left blank. I like this because it is both a symbol of Europe’s unwritten potential and that of integration being quite difficult and uncertain, but also the trust among those who were signing this blank sheet of paper that what they were doing together would be good for the future. They trusted each other because they wanted the best for our people and for our countries. Many of you referred to Robert Schuman’s famous statement that we would not build a common Europe, this important common project, all at once and in one go, but through consecutive victories on a long and hard path, and that this would be the moment when we would forge European solidarity. I think that, if the founding fathers were with us today, on one side they would be very much impressed at how we have filled that piece of paper with successes. But I am confident that they would also have a lot of inspiration about how to proceed further. I think that very soon they would realise, as Mr González Pons has pointed out, that it should be absolutely normal and natural to be a strong patriot and a strong European at the same time. We just want the best for our people, the best for our country and the best for our Europe. Sometimes I’m puzzled by how much proof we need to realise that, even in such a crisis as this, we do not have a single European country that can do a better job than if we do it all together as Europeans. Ms García Pérez, Mr Durand and Mr Benifei have underlined the importance of making the debate on the Conference on the Future of Europe as relevant as possible. I would like to thank you very much for the proposals which I heard that we should include the topics of recovery and the renewed need for solidarity, and that we should debate honestly about all subjects which matter to our citizens, even such pertinent questions as fair taxation and how we can improve our common fight against tax fraud and tax evasion, which was put Mr Durand and Ms Aubry. I agree with Ms García Pérez that the holidays look very different from what we are going through this spring. I think that we should thank all those who are working very hard, including you, honourable Members of the European Parliament, because, without your quick action, we wouldn’t have been able to adopt so many measures, which I believe saved many lives and will save millions of jobs. So now I think that the major lessons learned from the Schuman Declaration in our debate today are that we need to focus on immediate steps. We have to have an ambitious multiannual financial perspective. We have to have a recovery fund with strong firepower. We need to tackle the crisis, relaunch the economy and give a new boost to our European project through this intimate and in-depth debate with our citizens. I believe that this would be something that Robert Schuman would suggest to us and I think that this will be the best way to respect his legacy. (Applause)

name: Nikolina Brnjac
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, seventy years after the Schuman Declaration is a good moment to reflect about Europe, the challenges that face us and how we can continue to make sure the Union is effective in addressing them and delivering solutions.  As I said, in these challenging circumstances, the Presidency will do its utmost to steer our work in preparing and reaching the decision needed to address the COVID-19 crisis, as well as the impact on so many aspects of our lives. Active and effective cooperation between our institutions will be crucial in that regard.  In all these very difficult circumstances, as you know, my capital city, Zagreb, was hit by a strong earthquake on 22 March, leaving many of our citizens homeless and further traumatised on top of the COVID-19 pandemic. I thank everyone warmly for all the help and support we received. I hope that we will all learn from the experience of this crisis and work towards making Europe more resilient to similar or any other potential future crises, especially in protecting our supply chains, diversifying and bringing back to Europe end production of essential strategic goods and food in order to ensure Europe’s self-sustainability.  Regarding the Conference of the Future of Europe that indeed we planned launching on 9 May. As you will understand, in the last period, our work in the Council had focussed on the immediate priority of the response to the pandemic. However, we are determined to come back to it – first to reach a consensus on a Council position and then by negotiating among our institutions. A new target date for a launch of the conference should be agreed, and recent developments certainly need to be taken into consideration. To that effect, the Presidency had the first exchange with Member States already this week.

text: Thank you very much. With this speech we conclude the discussion on the 70th anniversary of the Schuman Declaration. Written declarations (Article 171)

name: Clara Aguilera (S&D)
text: in writing. – On the 70th anniversary of the founding of the EU, we faced the most difficult situation since 1950. The coronavirus pandemic leaves thousands of people deceased and an economic depression not remembered since 1929, adding to the challenges we faced over the past decade: climate change, aggressive geopolitics, migration crises, digital challenge, Brexit, and Trump's election in the U.S., among others.  In these seven decades Europe has experienced the longest period of peace and prosperity, equipping itself with the world's largest and most integrated internal market, the euro and a series of collective investment policies that have ensured political freedom, economic progress and social welfare. On 9 May 1950 Robert Schuman stated that Europe "would not be done at once, but by creating de facto solidarity" but also said that the ECSC was the first stage "for a European federation", a historic mission that we must complete. Europe must therefore be equipped with new tools to address the three crises we are currently in: public, economic and political health crises that we will only be able to address through a European health, financial and political union.

name: Joachim Stanisław Brudziński (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – We are in the middle of the next session of the European Parliament, which is taking place in Brussels, not Strasbourg, among a dozen or not hundreds of Members in the plenary chamber. We vote by correspondence, in offices, not in the plenary chamber. Why? Because this is not an ordinary time and these are not ordinary circumstances. Therefore, specific remedies are needed not only in Brussels, but also throughout Europe and around the world. And such measures and actions were taken by the government in Budapest. Unfortunately, this debate shows how much the actions of the European institutions can be detached from reality. However, the institutions can be consistent: every opportunity to strike at the Hungarian Government is being exploited. It seeks all possible and impossible means of 'the existence of a clear risk of a serious breach by a Member State of the values referred to in Article 2 of the [Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union]'.  I call on the European Parliament, the Council and, in particular, the European Commission, to focus at this particular time on cooperation and cooperation in the fight against the epidemic itself and its consequences (if it has not been properly or at least better prepared for this situation), and not to return with a particular penchant for finding threats to democracy in the Hungarian state, which is fighting for its citizens.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: in writing. – The 70th anniversary of the Schuman Declaration, the first step in the construction of Europe, comes at the most difficult time for Europe since the end of the Second World War, but the full importance of the declaration and the implicit ideal of 'an ever closer union' is even more evident. The unprecedented health, economic and social crisis that the Covid-19 pandemic has generated shows that the awareness contained in the declaration is always current, that Europe must arise "from concrete achievements that first create de facto solidarity", and that only "an organized and vital Europe" can really contribute, as well as "to civilization" and to the "maintenance of peaceful relations", to the protection of its citizens and to the promotion of the values of freedom , equality, justice, legality, protection of fundamental rights and respect for the rule of law. The need for solidarity, coordination and joint action, which undersea the declaration, has never been more evident: in particular, in the immediate as well as in the medium and long term, European solidarity is and will be crucial if no one is left behind. It is therefore essential to strengthen the European institutions and policies, their effectiveness and democracy: only by persevering in the spirit of the declaration will the Union be able to face the difficult challenges that the current historic moment poses.

name: Johan Danielsson (S&D)
text: Written. The EU was founded to secure peace, strengthen trade, create jobs and give confidence in the future. This year is the 70th anniversary of the Schuman Declaration. Europe has changed drastically since then. The EU has succeeded in maintaining peace in Europe and cooperation has deepened. However, this development has not always benefited workers and trade unions. It is important to have an EU that solves the common problems of the Member States. At the same time, the EU must respect trade union rights and freedoms, giving countries political and legal room for manoeuvre to bring order to the labour market. The interests of rogue companies in crossing borders cannot be superior to trade union rights.  We need a Europe that contributes to the fight against growing inequality, unfair competition and social dumping. A Europe that creates a floor of protection and rights for workers in the internal market, and which limits the unilateral profit interests of global corporate giants and closes the doors to tax avoidance. It is crucial for the future of Europe that we succeed in running a policy that delivers for ordinary people. That is the basis for us Social Democrats. And it is with this insight that I am working towards a more ambitious European strategy on health and safety at work, for greater opportunities to organise themselves and to conclude collective agreements, and for better conditions for Member States to ensure equal treatment of workers.

name: György Hölvényi (PPE)
text: Writing. – On the 70th anniversary of the declaration of French Christian Democratic Foreign Minister Robert Schuman, we can conclude that the European Union is resliing its legacy, all the intellectual and moral capital from which integration has been feeding with unprecedented success for decades. Instead of solving our urgent tasks, replacing the common European path in the 21st century, the left-wing political mainstream uses the EU institutions as a playground for party politics, far beyond their original function, namely European legislation. We clearly see that this "elite" is letting the Robert Schuman legacy go to its perishables. Moreover, this tradition is simply denied by certain political groups. As they talk about unprecedented close cooperation, they are threspers on the side of anyone who is not on their side, especially non-left-wing governments. All this is a long process that shows increasingly extreme examples. Part of this is the repeated attack on my country, which we witnessed in this morning's plenary debate – within the usual concept framework.  The constant, yet unfounded, crosshairs of the other side are a mockery of Schuman's legacy, but they don't care at all. The European Parliament has now become part of and facilitating this 'game'. Our most important task is to find a way to change that. I believe that the Robert Schuman legacy means this too: not to let it. His legacy remains key to overcoming our current crisis and remaining European unity.

name: Virginie Joron (ID)
text: In writing. No to the construction of a 400-seat bar and a second European Parliament in Brussels, let us use the buildings in Strasbourg, the official seat of the European Parliament. Since 1958, Strasbourg has been the seat of the European Parliament because it symbolizes the Franco-German reconciliation initiated by Schuman. For Strasbourg, Parliament has 11,000 jobs and 637 million euros a year. However, in 1993, a second parliament was (badly) built in Brussels. The cathedrals lasted 1,000 years but this building will soon be destroyed. Demolition was postponed after the European elections to avoid scandal. Reconstruction will cost at least 0.5 billion euros. The draft provides for 900 seats for deputies, i.e. 200 extra seats (is it for the 96 Turkish MPs) and 940 bar places for MPs and their collaborators compared to 1,260 seats in meeting rooms. All the anti-Strasbourg hide these pharaonic expenses to come, promise less CO2 and 616 million euros by selling the Strasbourg Parliament and firing its staff. The reverse strategy, which would be to concentrate activities in Strasbourg, has never been studied. For the COVID-19 epidemic in the world, the EU gave the Maghreb 775 million. Democracy is not for sale.

name: Karol Karski (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – 70 years ago Robert Schuman made a declaration that became the foundation of the European Union as we know it today. With this gesture, an extraordinary political project was launched, which provided 70 years of peace and prosperity. I am proud that, over the years, we have succeeded in creating an economic and political community based on Christian roots and European values such as solidarity, freedom, tolerance, equality in diversity and respect for the rule of law.  I regret that such an important anniversary is being celebrated at a time when the European Union is facing one of the most difficult challenges since its inseening: the health, economic and social crisis caused by the COVID-19 pandemic. However, each crisis makes it difficult to draw conclusions and can be an excellent opportunity for further development, as it points to our weaknesses and shortcomings. Let's take advantage of that.  I am sure that the founding fathers of the European Union would be surprised at how much their project has developed. On the other hand, the 70th anniversary of the creation of the European Community may be a good time to stop and think about whether we should rethink the direction in which we are going, to remind ourselves of the principles of subsidiarity, European solidarity and equality for all Member States. Indeed, it seems that these values are too often forgotten in Brussels, and especially in the European Parliament.

name: Илхан Кючюк (Renew)
text: in writing. – Today we know that the unification of Europe is a complex process. It will be built on achievements that create a sense of solidarity and trust. A trust that builds the foundations of a new, working and united Europe.  70 years after schuman's declaration and thanks to the efforts of visionaries and generations of Europeans, peace and prosperity are today the core ideals of our common continent. The dream of millions of citizens has been realized, but we also realize that differences are wealth. From countries fragmented and destroyed by devastating wars, Europe today sets global standards for democracy, human rights and freedoms and the rule of law. For these 70 years, Europe has been at a crossroads many times. A crossroads of tough elections and hopes.  Today, Europe faces a similar choice. We need courage, ambition and solidarity to shape the future. Only then will we be able to meet the expectations of our citizens, but I believe that together we will be able to build Europe for all Europeans!
