name: Dace Melbārde (ECR)
text: Writing. – "The idea of a united Europe will no longer be a poets' theme or a utopian vision; it will be a living reality, because the conscience of the People of Europe will have realised that this idea is an opportunity for their escape." Now, with a critical analysis of the initial response of the Member States and also of the Institutions of the European Union to the pandemic, we can see that we were able to quickly find a basis for common values for effective cooperation. This is also due to the fact that patients from one country's pandemic-stricken regions are accepted by neighbouring hospitals. We are woven into a common economic, political and cultural network that we feel particularly clearly when suddenly locked borders remind many of an even recent past that seems so distant at the same time, but for others it is unprecedented. Europe's freedoms have become so self-evident. Covid-19 is an opportunity to set aside the disagreements of recent years, which have soothed doubts about the EU's political identity, and show mutual trust and trust through concrete deeds. This includes agreeing on a recovery plan that pays particular attention to tackling social inequalities and a shared vision for the future of Europe at the Conference on the Future of Europe, without leaving anyone behind. The fundamental values of Europe that shape Europe are also at the heart of our future: peace and solidarity.

name: Leszek Miller (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The Schuman Declaration is a cornerstone of the European Communities and of today's Union. While celebrating the 70th anniversary of its signature, it is worth recalling, however, that this declaration, also known as the Schuman Plan, concerned not only the sectoral coordination of coal mining and steel production in the ECSC countries, but above all the idea of creating a European federation based on common values based on Greek philosophy, Roman law and Christian humanism. This overarching objective of the Schuman Declaration was transferred in 1957 to the treaty of Rome and is still coded there today as a process of creating an ever closer union between the peoples of Europe.  We are now in a special moment of integration. On the one hand, we are celebrating the 70th anniversary of the signing of the Schuman Declaration and the decade of the Treaty of Lisbon, on the other hand, we are experiencing an unprecedented pandemic crisis with multidimensional health, economic and institutional consequences. The European Union and the Member States should use this moment to take a step forward and to emerge from this crisis strengthened. Not only on the basis of the pro-integration mechanisms contained in the Treaty of Lisbon (bridging clauses), but also by developing more far-reaching proposals, m.in. on strengthening the position of the European Parliament, introducing the general principle of qualified majority voting in the Council or constitutionalising the European Pillar of Social Rights. The conference on the future of Europe will certainly be an excellent opportunity to do so.

name: Urmas Paet (Renew)
text: Writing. – The idea of a united Europe was to avoid another war. And so far, so has it been. The European Union is a peace project and a united Europe has lived in peace and without wars. Europe's strength is also Estonia's strength. To this end, however, we particularly need a strong and united Europe that knows what freedoms mean, and also how easy it is to lose them.  In today's and tomorrow's worlds, it is important that Estonian foreign policy acts every day for two main objectives. These are the security of Estonia and the increase in prosperity. It is important that a country with a geopolitical position and history in Estonia keeps and contributes to allied relations with countries that share the same values with us. Estonia's allies are primarily in Europe and in other democratic worlds. It is therefore necessary to contribute to Estonia's day-to-day activities in order to ensure that the European Union and NATO are strong and functioning in order to achieve its major foreign policy objectives. There is no place to take estonia's security and well-being. Anything that weakens Europe's cooperation should be avoided now and in the years to come. Unfortunately, other forces in a very different value space take care of this.

name: Guido Reil (ID)
text: Writing. – 70 years ago, the then French Foreign Minister, Robert Schuman, made his statement, which is celebrated as the beginning of the process of European integration and the birth of today's European Union. Basically, the German and French coal and steel industries have been removed from national control and placed under a common European authority. This has secured peace in Europe. What is unknown today is that Robert Schuman, like Jean Monnet, and other advocates of European integration also embraced the idea of A Eurafrica. Access to African raw materials would allow Europe to stay as a strong continent. When the European Economic Community (EEC) was founded in 1957, France still had a comprehensive colonial empire. The system of preferential duties and financial assistance was a prerequisite for the French Government's accession to the EEC. France saw the Euro-African Free Trade Area as a means of maintaining its hegemony in and over West Africa. It is interesting that in the wake of the mission of civilization of the Berlin Conference (1884–1885), which formally divided Africa, both the Schuman Declaration and the EEC described the Association of Overseas African Territories as an instrument for improving Africa's development. In several later translations of the Declaration, the relevant sentences of that declaration were deleted.

name: Alfred Sant (S&D)
text: in writing. – On 9 May 1950, the Schuman declaration launched the political and economic construction of Europe. Its central genial premise was that Europe could be peacefully united by concentrating on concrete step by step measures to enable convergence between its national economies via the establishment of a single common market. National and regional interests would be taken into account in a detailed give-and-take, creating a shared European acquis. Though very successful, this approach was fundamentally rejigged in the 1990’s, following the collapse of the USSR. Rapid deepening and enlargement became the order of the day, sometimes run in a hegemonic manner. The deepening such as with the eurozone but also Schengen was left half done. Fast enlargement has led to spreading political and economic divergences within the Union. Now, Union members find themselves increasingly unable to agree on concrete sectoral policies, for which the Union has at least partial competence. Among them: migration; long term Union budgeting; eurozone financial management; dealings with Russia and the US; a containment and recovery strategy vis-à-vis the corona virus pandemic; and soon possibly a final solution with the UK post-Brexit. Robert Schumann would not have been amused. We have gotten far away from the strategy he set.

name: Valdemar Tomaševski (ECR)
text: Writing. – The 70th anniversary of the Schuman Declaration is on the 70th anniversary. He talked about building a community in Europe, but not as we see it today. The modern EU has little to do with the ideas of a politician who is based on Christianity and considers the existence of nations to be something obvious and necessary. All politicians who, in silence, bypass the true ideas of a politician, not only swipe his vision, but destroy the fruits that have emerged from the agreement according to his concept. Let us remember on this anniversary the real words of the father of the founder of the European Community, perhaps they will once again touch the conscience of European politicians. Schuman has repeatedly warned of dangerous consequences for deviating from Christian values, the elimination of communities of nations, institutional and economic dominance over real relations between the people. Among many warnings, he said, "Beware of those whose charm leads us to passivity. Those who want to put us to sleep in a false sense of security. Beware of empty guarantee providers who promise deceptive security measures. In stages and step by step they try to introduce what the healthy spirit of the nation rejects. Their ultimate goal is clear. They are trying to put an end to religious life in countries and people. Because of our love for our children, we want to prevent these consequences. Our posture, which we accept, should not arise only because of resistance, but mainly because we cannot betray the spirit of our people." In the dispute over the future format of the European Union, it is worth remembering another idea by Mr Schuman: 'Democracy will be Christian or will not be at all'.

name: Presidente. –
text: We move on to the next item on our agenda, and what is on the agenda is, as you know, the statements by the Council and the Commission on the use of computer applications for locating and tracing contacts in the fight against coronavirus (2020/2634(RSP)). I would like to remind you that in this debate, as in the previous ones, there will be no catch-the-eye procedures or questions in the form of a 'blue card'.

name: Nikolina Brnjac
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, thank you for this opportunity to address the European Parliament on an issue so closely related to the COVID—19 pandemic. The work on COVID—19 contact tracing applications fits within the more general work to ensure a safe return to our normal social and economic activity as quickly as the circumstances allow. Contact tracing applications can help restore life in the European Union as we used to know and appreciate it – the unrestricted movement of people, goods and services – while upholding the highest health and safety standards. They would support the revival of our tourism, aviation and shipping industries. We have followed with interest the statements and declarations coming from the European Parliament, especially the resolution on EU coordinated action to combat the COVID—19 pandemic and its consequences. As you are aware, the Commission presented its recommendation on 8 April 2020 on a common Union toolbox for the use of technology and data to combat and exit from the COVID—19 crisis. All Member States welcomed the initiative and there was overall agreement that this technology is a key element in the mix of measures for the exit strategy. On 9 April, the European Data Protection Board also issued its guidance on this subject. When the Ministers responsible for telecommunications and digital issues held an informal videoconference on 5 May, they reached consensus on the need to ensure the interoperability of national applications. At this point in time, we have national solutions – some already working, some under development. To save time and effort, work on interoperability should take into account the progress already made at the national level. We must also make sure that, irrespective of the technical solutions adopted, these apps are trusted enough to be used by our citizens in large enough numbers. This will not happen unless the apps can be used on a voluntary basis, ensure adequate protection of personal data and privacy and avoid the stigmatisation or any potential misuse of the collected and stored data. There is a need for a joint shared approach and common standards in developing such apps. These apps should do nothing more than trace contacts. Malfunctioning of the app could potentially change the life of our users, so the efficiency of the application should always be checked. It is also important to mention that there are sizeable regional differences between digital services across and between the different Member States. We must ensure digital inclusion in every part of Europe. Bridging this gap will not happen without investments, interconnectivity, technological and human digital skills. In this respect, the Croatian Presidency is working on the Council conclusions as our answer to the Commission communication on shaping Europe’s digital future. The issues include the resilience of our digital infrastructure, the importance of reliable data availability at the European level, the urgency of implementing our e—health initiatives, the importance of improving the digital aspects of our education, our security, of our networks and data. All these aspects will be covered in the Council conclusions.

name: Didier Reynders
text: membre de la Commission. – Monsieur le Président, Mesdames et Messieurs les membres du Parlement européen, je voudrais vous remercier également d’avoir inclus ce débat dans la plénière d’aujourd’hui. La pandémie qui sévit actuellement ne connaît pas de frontières. Les données et la technologie peuvent nous aider dans la lutte contre le coronavirus et dans la levée progressive des restrictions et le rétablissement de la libre circulation des personnes. Les applications de traçage des contacts peuvent jouer un rôle dans cette entreprise. The Commission adopted the recommendation on 8 April setting out the principles and showing the respect of fundamental rights and, in particular, the right to privacy and personal data protection and the prevention of mass surveillance and stigmatisation. It was followed by a common EU toolbox developed by the Member States with the support of the Commission and complemented by Commission guidance on the respect of privacy and data protection.  Our guidance sets key principles. National health authorities or authorities responsible for the crisis management should be the controller. The installation of an app on a user’s device should be voluntary. If proximity data is used, it should be stored on an individual’s device and only shared at the initiative of the user.  For contact tracing there is no use of geo-localisation data, only proximity data based on Bluetooth. Only the personal data that is necessary to meet the purpose of the app can be processed. The identity of the user of the app will not be disclosed to other users. The personal data should not be kept for longer than necessary. Timelines should be based on medical relevance. In addition, the app should be only used during the crisis and be deactivated, at the latest, when the pandemic is over.  The deactivation should not depend on de-installation by the user. The data and the entire application should be protected through state-of-the-art security techniques, including encryption. And finally, data protection authorities should be fully involved and consulted in the development of an app and should keep its deployment under review.  Le but des applications de traçage des contacts est d’aider à briser les chaînes d’infection et à sauver des vies. Cependant, cela ne fonctionnera que si les citoyens savent qu’ils sont en sécurité et que leurs données et leur vie privée sont entièrement protégées. Les citoyens doivent avoir la certitude que les applications seront utilisées exclusivement pour lutter contre la pandémie. Ce sont là les conditions préalables au développement, à la reconnaissance et à l’utilisation de telles applications.  J’insiste sur ce point: il ne doit pas y avoir de doute. Ces applications ne peuvent pas être utilisées pour une surveillance de masse. Les individus garderont et devront garder le contrôle de leurs données. C’est le fondement de la précision et de l’efficacité de ces applications pour contenir la propagation du virus.  Il est donc essentiel d’identifier les solutions les moins intrusives et qui respectent pleinement les exigences de protection des données personnelles et de confidentialité telles que définies dans le droit de l’Union européenne. It is also essential that we have a coordinated European approach. This European approach is clear. These apps must be voluntary, transparent, temporary, cyber-secure, using temporary and arbitrary identifiers, rely on proximity data, Bluetooth technology and not on geo-localisation. That means no tracking. And they must be interoperable across borders, but also across operating systems.  As regards the two different approaches referred to as centralised and decentralised, both can be compatible with privacy and data-protection rules, and both need to follow high standards of data security. From a data-minimisation perspective, the decentralised approach is preferable since less data would be stored on the back-end server than under the centralised one. Regardless of the approach chosen, we should strive to have a common approach to ensure interoperability of the apps. The Commission is working with Member States on this issue as a top priority, and I am glad that guidelines on interoperability for approved contact tracing mobile applications in the EU were adopted yesterday by the e-Health networks of Member States and published on the Commission website. I cannot emphasise enough how important interoperability will be for the cross-border circulation of people in the Union and for many sectors, including tourism.  We should also make sure that national health authorities are able to adjust the epidemiologic barometers of the apps and to obtain the necessary aggregated information to monitor the efficiency of the measures taken.  The Commission also firmly believes that the process regarding the selection of the apps as well as their functioning, should be transparent. The technical specifications and the source code of the apps should therefore be published.  Some Member States are using manual tracing together or instead of tracing apps. Their tracing modalities need to be in line with personal data protection rules as well. We will also be attentive to this.  Mesdames et Messieurs les députés, comme nous le savons tous, les États membres ont commencé à introduire les premières étapes des mesures de déconfinement. C’est pourquoi nous avons besoin d’une approche européenne coordonnée. Nous devons agir ensemble avec responsabilité et solidarité pour arrêter ce virus. Monsieur le Président, je vous remercie de cette occasion de préciser les lignes de force annoncées par la Commission en collaboration avec les États membres. Je suis évidemment à l’écoute des remarques, des observations des membres de votre Assemblée.

name: Andreas Schwab
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has It is undoubtedly good news that border controls in Central Europe will now be largely lifted from the weekend onwards and in full by mid-June.  This pandemic must not set a back of this pandemic for a free Europe of 100 years. What is important now, however, is that citizens use their slowly re-emerging freedom responsibly. And as a hygiene professor from Denmark told us this week, hygiene and distance are not everything in life. But without hygiene and without distance, everything we do now is nothing. That's why it's all about keeping your distance and washing your hands.  In this case, however, Europe can, of course, make it easier for citizens to enjoy their freedom and use by providing digital support if they have been at risk of contagion. That is why, Commissioner, you were quite right to point out the conditions which are of particular importance to my group.  We believe that this app will convince many citizens if it offers them something – if it provides them with security, when it provides them with information, and if it is useful for them. It must work everywhere in Europe. So it has to be operal. The Member States are called upon to do this, because the health systems of the Member States are still organised differently. And it must bring a few other things, namely no geolocation, anonymity, use must be voluntary. It must be protected against any kind of cyberattack. And it must be deleted as soon as it is no longer needed.  Health protection is a public task. In this case, however, it is precisely the citizens' own responsibility that we must take into account. That's why I hope this app will be available soon.

name: Birgit Sippel
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, are contact tracing apps a silver bullet against the virus? Today, there is no evidence that apps can contain a disease, but there are serious fundamental rights concerns, and therefore the app must be truly voluntary, with no incentives to use them and no discrimination against people not willing to use them or who cannot use them. Entry into a country should not depend on using the app. Freedom of movement is a fundamental right, not a prize for downloading an app.  Apps must only be used for contact tracing with no access for commercial players or law enforcement, and data should be stored in a decentralised way. This is important because, especially in exceptional times, interference with fundamental rights must remain proportionate, necessary and limited in time. Governments now have a chance to show that Europe can lead the way in countering this pandemic without compromising on fundamental rights.  So why is it that only a few Member States fully involved their data protection authorities? What are they afraid of? We can’t accept any ideas to install systems of surveillance via contact tracing apps or by using location data, drones, or by openly debating to discriminate on the basis of so-called immunity passes?  Let’s be honest: there is nothing like a silver bullet. Even a fundamental rights-friendly app can only be an addition to physical distancing, masks and more tests. Technologies and the crisis should never be used to destroy our common values and democratic principles, but let us explore how technology can help to better protect people.

name: Karen Melchior
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Mr President, I say to the House: without knowing, you could be infected right now. I, too, could be infected. Without showing a single sign of infection, I could be infecting the people I stand next to. Digital technology is a tool in the fight against the spread of COVID-19, and it can be both beneficial and effective to trace contacts in order to notify people at risk.  The use of the applications must be strictly and exclusively limited to the purpose of COVID-19 tracing. Tracing applications should assist manual tracing used for centuries to combat epidemics. Applications are not a panacea to combat the virus, but a complementary tool. We have to trace the virus, not the European citizens. We unite against the coronavirus while we safeguard our fundamental rights. We must insist on mandatory standards and strong guarantees for their preservation, especially the right to privacy and data protection. We do not have to choose between our rights and our health. We must ensure ethical, transparent and secure use of these applications. Therefore, we need a European coordinated approach also ensuring European-wide interoperability.  Firstly, we must agree at a European level on privacy by design and data minimisation. Secondly, using such applications must be based on the explicit, freely given and informed consent. It should never be mandatory. We do not want immunity passports. We want to stop the virus from travelling. Thirdly, technology will not be effective without the trust of people. Citizens need to receive adequate and objective information on tracing contact policies, their content, their purpose and expected outcomes. Finally, the use and deployment of contact tracing applications must be subject to continuous and strict monitoring, technical evaluation and scientific scrutiny. We must ensure that these applications are safe for our citizens and have their trust, and that the applications serve the purpose of tracing COVID-19.

name: Jean-Lin Lacapelle
text: on behalf of the ID Group. - Mr President, while we can understand the health security objective that drives the establishment of a number of tracing applications, I would like to mention a number of areas of uncertainty that persist around, both the exploitation of this personal data that will be collected, and their destruction. First of all, with respect to their exploitation, how can you guarantee us the complete confidentiality of the data that will be collected? Who will exploit them? You mentioned health authorities earlier, but what is their composition? Are they medical? If so, fine. Are they political authorities? If that is the case, it is a real problem. Finally, with regard to the destruction of this collected data, who will order the destruction operations? That is the first question I ask. Second, how soon? What sanctions, too, are provided? As far as the time frame is concerned, we want it to be done immediately after the end, the extinction of the epidemic. And then, who will control these operations of destruction, in order to preserve the individual freedoms of our compatriots, as well as of course all the confidentiality of this collected data?

name: Alexandra Geese
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has Only with the confidence of citizens could tracing apps be a helpful tool in the fight against the Corona virus and also a flagship project of value-based European digital technology. After all, a consortium of European universities has developed a standard that meets the high data protection requirements that our citizens rightly demand. In return, many are willing to install this app, but it takes confidence to do so. That is why it is so dangerous for governments to jeopardise this trust by insisting on central storage or by tying politicians to special rights or even obligations to this app. So anyone who wants citizens to be able to have confidence must also have confidence in them and abandon any fantasy of control and monitoring. This is where we have the opportunity to prove that free democracies can successfully fight the virus. Because with this app, trust, data protection and health go hand in hand.

name: Beata Mazurek
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by The fight against the coronavirus pandemic can have different faces. On the one hand, we have medics who put their health and lives at risk by standing on the front line of the fight against the invisible enemy, and on the other hand, technological advances make it possible to introduce solutions that will limit the spread of plague.  We agree with the methods proposed by the Commission, they can help us in this, but it is not entirely clear how this tool will work. The commission should prioritise the protection of users' privacy and sensitive information should be stored in accordance with applicable data protection rules. It is necessary to work together and exploit the potential of Member States with experience in developing similar applications, such as Poland, where we have an application to control people in quarantine, and more recently the ProteGO application, which informs about the potential risk of coronavirus infection.  We need to use new technologies to fight coronavirus. However, let us remember that these solutions must be adapted to the conditions of individual Member States in order to effectively protect their citizens.

name: Anne-Sophie Pelletier
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL group. Mr President, this crisis shows once again the failures of your system. Among them, the lack of resources in hospitals, medical equipment, dependence on China, destruction of the industrial fabric. Those who told us that there is no magic money are the same people who sacrificed our public health services on the altar of austerity, following the Commission's 63 recommendations, which were aimed at privatising and reducing spending. 63 recommendations later, caregivers and hospitals are cracking. 63 recommendations later, we count the dead. So modern Harpagons, instead of repairing what they've broken, present a miracle cure: contact tracking applications. To the peoples of solidarity who have accepted and respected the containment, we are still asking to sacrifice their freedom. The assurances you give from the Privacy Commission are not convincing. There is no credibility, whereas in Hungary and Latvia these rights are suspended. And while our SMEs are dying, GAFAM across the Atlantic is eating up. Do we also have to give them our data through these applications? You want, Mr Reynders, to save lives. Well, massively test the citizens, give extra resources, learn from your mistakes, invest in the public hospital rather than playing sorcerer's apprentices with our freedoms. And I would like not to repeat that 63 times.

name: Laura Ferrara (NI).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the Member States are preparing to phase out the containment measures and at this stage, which is clearly not without its concerns, the use of technologies and applications for alerting, preventing and tracking contacts will make an important contribution to the fight against coronavirus. European citizens who voluntarily decide to use them expect full compliance with rules and principles on the protection of personal data, as well as respect for private and family life, respect for the principle of non-discrimination and freedom of movement. Clear and transparent information campaigns on their operation, use and retention of data will therefore be essential, so that the purpose of helping to combat the pandemic and alerting in case of potential risks of contagion is understandable. In Italy, the Italian government has announced the launch of Immuni, an app that will allow proximity tracking without collecting personal data capable of revealing identities, where you go or who you meet, therefore a valid tool aimed only at the responsible use of data for the protection of public health, without undermining fundamental rights and individual freedoms.

name: Axel Voss (PPE).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the The extreme crisis ultimately requires a return to everyday life as quickly as possible, and testing, protective masks and even tracing apps help. It is also obvious that we must work together at European level here, and that also means that we must quickly present the necessary standards in the future. The Commission's recommendations were very laudable in terms of data protection, interoperability, but at the beginning of this development the interoperable apps with the technical specifications were missing, and this ultimately leads to fragmentation. I must also ask myself why the Council itself does not come up with the idea of saying that we must also work together in this crisis and perhaps give a shining example in this cooperation, and that is why more work needs to be done here on the Council's attitude. The EU must take the lead here, especially in such an extreme crisis. We need to act together, including in the digital world, and look at the efficiency of these whole tracing apps from the point of view of what is really efficient and leads forward.

name: Paul Tang (S&D).
text: – Mr President, perhaps contacts tracking apps in combination with tests can help us live with the coronavirus. From fundamental freedoms, there are four conditions. It should be temporary, transparent and therefore open source, decentralized with storage on the phone, and voluntary. Anyone who can't or won't use the app should not be denied access. The apps must not become immunity passports. In addition, the apps must work across borders across europe. This is necessary for Europe. That was agreed yesterday. They must be strictly observed. Finally, let us not forget why it is so difficult for Minister De Jonge and the other countries to develop the app. We depend on Silicon Valley for the development of the apps. Google and Apple are the gatekeepers of our phones and therefore essential to our health. So let's also look at how we can develop a vaccine against the dependence of big technology companies.

name: Sophia in ‘t Veld (Renew).
text: – Mr President, I’ve heard some people refer to this app as a so-called ‘deconfinement app’, as if the app is going to reopen the borders. Well, let me tell you something. It will not. We need a range of other measures. What will open the borders is a common European approach and interoperability. That is what will open the borders. What we are seeing is Member States going in all directions again, with not just 27 national apps, but even a range of regional apps. Now that is a barrier to free movement. National governments are presenting the app as a silver bullet against the pandemic, but not only is it not a silver bullet, it’s also not going to solve the problem of politicians that they have to reconcile health concerns and economic concerns and are just hoping for this app to be the answer to that dilemma when it’s not.  But we do need full transparency on the decision—making – and not just on the technical aspects, but also on why governments choose a particular model, why they choose particular providers. Where are the political and commercial interests?  Finally, I agree with everyone who said it must be strictly voluntary. Not only does that mean that it should not be mandatory, but there has to be a legal ban on making downloading the app a precondition for entering public spaces like public transport or schools or gyms, or indeed crossing the borders, because freedom of movement in Europe is a fundamental right.

name: David Cormand (Verts/ALE).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, contact tracking applications are presented to us as an absolute necessity to deal with COVID. But nothing is less certain. Bluetooth, for example, is not effective in detecting who has been the subject of risky contact. Its detection range is well over one and a half meters and it does not detect walls or floors. But, above all, this system endorses the idea, democratically mortal, that in the name of the best general interest, people can be accustomed to an additional incursion into their private lives. So let's put it simply: not only is mass surveillance not a solution, but it is also a proven danger to our fundamental freedoms. Some say this process would be temporary. But recent history shows that our democracies fail to restore the freedoms they suspend in times of crisis. Every setback is final. Our responsibility is therefore not to give in to fear or emotion, and to stand firm in the face of the deceptive sirens of greater security offered by this technology.

name: Dino Giarrusso (NI).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, it is a good thing that the European Commission has provided guidelines for the apps that will ensure traceability of infections, and it is also essential to pay attention to the privacy of citizens, but equally to ensure the transparency of the companies that develop the apps, so that there are no conflicts of interest that would undermine precisely the protection of users' data and the credibility of these tools. These instruments must soon lead us to the reopening of Schengen, they must lead us to safely guaranteed mobility right at the gates of the tourist season in Europe, thus showing a Europe united in difficulties and not only in diversity. Indeed, I would have seen a single app for all Member States to avoid possible disparities, and in this regard I reiterate Italy's total opposition to agreements such as those envisaged in recent days by some countries on phantom "tourism corridors" between Member States, which would create unfair commercial practices penalising precisely those who have moved before, and better than others, in combating the coronavirus.

name: Isabel Wiseler-Lima (PPE).
text: Mr President, we are fortunate in Europe to have exceptional protection of personal data. Our data is stored only with our consent. However, we can sometimes be very generous with our data and make it available to commercial companies, social networks where we calibrate our movements, applications that record our steps, the very rhythm of our heart. It's quite special but it's everyone's free choice. Would we arrogate the right to ban it? Of course not. So I have some difficulty understanding the fear that can be instilled in people willing to use a tracking application to better control the spread of COVID-19. An application that is not used for commercial purposes, but for the common good, by public institutions. An application installed and used on a voluntary basis, which requires the user's consent at every step and complies with EU law.  Where and when is the individual's freedom threatened? Such an application, as an element that allows me to provide some additional security to my family, my entourage and others, it is almost a duty for the public authorities to make it available to citizens and to inform them as best they can.

name: Patrick Breyer (Verts/ALE).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Edward Snowden is not the only one to warn that permanent control and surveillance structures are being built in the shadow of the Corona pandemic.  Although the pandemic in Europe is now under control, governments want to make a return to our normal lives conditional on us embarking on a social experiment for digital behavioral capture. So far, it is people who ask and notify contact persons of infected persons. According to studies, this protects us much better than any app and avoids massive false alarms. Who of you really believes that a contact recording technology once introduced will remain voluntary throughout Europe? That is an illusion.  Dear governments, finally provide adequate protective equipment and health care, test offers, vaccine supply, provide for future pandemics. You owe it to us, not surveillance technology and data collection!

name: Clara Ponsatí Obiols (NI).
text: – Mr President, COVID-19 is also testing us digitally. Health systems can look after their citizens without geolocation and undue control of their privacy. With or without COVID—19, governments do not need to know where citizens are at all times. There are technologies aligned with these principles and it is not acceptable that EU governments use invasive software. We do not need to go to China to see alarming practices. Spain is routinely censoring websites and apps. GitHub has been pressured by the Spanish Government to censor codes, and the Government of Pedro Sánchez recently hinted at plans to use an app that would track citizens to see if they change regions. This is happening within the EU and should not be tolerated. Europe must lead by example, safeguarding civil rights and individual freedom, including in the digital world.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, we, as countries of the European Union, have identified the problem as one of the many challenges we are facing: the problem is, once again, a unified position within which the Member States show an awareness of the Community dimension. Even on this game of applications we moved with a certain embarrassed and partial ability to share. We have two problems: the first is the identification of the correct technology, you have been very clear, a technology compatible with the protection of privacy. The second is the identification of a common model for dealing with these problems, because implementation is not enough to solve the problem: it is an integration of what, as a tool for the protection of people in health and social terms, we will have been able to share.

name: Didier Reynders
text: Member of the Commission. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I think it was appropriate that we should have the opportunity to re-debate this issue here in the plenary. And this debate clearly demonstrates the central role of the common work that can be carried out between institutions during this crisis. I would stress first of all that the extraordinary measures we must take to combat the pandemic must not compromise the foundation of our European project, our values and fundamental rights. The use of an application is never, as Mr Schwab or Mrs Sippel have pointed out, as a complementary element that is added to a whole range of others: hygiene rules, rules of social distance or tests to be carried out in large numbers. All of these elements are part of a whole. I would like to stress a very special point that has been mentioned several times: interoperability. If we want an effective Community project, we need real interoperability, regardless of the number of applications in the states or regions. That is what we are working on with the various states. I believe that it is better to allow different applications to develop than to want a single application at European level at all costs, which would probably have hindered innovation in this project. I would also like to emphasize security. We are very focused on cybersecurity and regardless of which operators want to develop applications (Apple, Google or others), they will have to comply with European data protection, security and interoperability rules. It is not in this Parliament that I would need to reiterate the importance of the general data protection regulation. We have tools, control and implementation.  National data protection authorities exist, they are grouped in a European-level council, the European Data Protection Committee and I can tell you that already today, certain measures taken especially in emergency measures during the pandemic are being examined by this European network to verify their compatibility with the provisions of the General Regulation. , this is particularly the case for a number of decrees adopted in Hungary. I would like to stress that everything we announce in our guidelines can be controlled not only by the national authorities, but also by a European network that exchanges and will look for the best way to apply the rules that we recall rather than set them because these rules are in the general regulation. And we will remain particularly vigilant about the use that will be made of tracing applications. They can make an important contribution to the fight against the COVID-19 pandemic, but we must ensure that our values and data protection rules are fully respected by all operators. I would also like to make it clear that transparency and communication are essential for the effective use of applications. That is why we intervened very early, with a recommendation on the toolbox and guidelines on the application of our data protection rules. I would like to say to Mr Lacapelle that if we intend to hand over the management of these applications to the health authorities, it is because they are particularly aware of the confidentiality of medical data and professional secrecy and that they also have the capacity to fully define the relevant epidemiological parameters of these applications. With a view to reopening borders and supporting the internal market, we must first pay attention to interoperability and observe a common approach.  Finally, we will focus on the voluntary nature of these applications and ensure that they are not indirectly tried to make them more or less mandatory, especially when it comes to crossing borders. This is something that I will be very attentive to and raise awareness among national data protection authorities.  I thank you once again for this debate, Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, because it is important that we act early enough to ensure that this tool, among others, helps us to fight the pandemic and get out of the crisis in conditions that fully respect our values and data protection. Europe has been a pioneer in the protection of personal data, and must remain so during the crisis and after the crisis.

name: Nikolina Brnjac
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, this is an important subject, and I would therefore like to underline once more the main points of the telecommunications ministers’ videoconference from the beginning of May. First, the contact tracing apps will have high importance for the gradual relaxation of various national measures, including opening of borders. Second, the coordinated approach and interoperability at EU level is needed. And third, adequate protection of personal data and privacy should be provided. Whatever technological solutions the Member States choose, the use of their apps should be based on consent, and storage should be ensured at the highest level of privacy and the protection of personal data. Interoperability will be the key to the success of these applications across borders and operative systems. Additionally, it should be encouraged that all the data collected through the tracing app is stored in a clearly defined time-limited manner. I am grateful for the opportunity to discuss this important subject with all of you, and thank you for your remarks and suggestions, I took good note of them. And I am sure that our institutions’ common aim is to find the most effective solutions for tackling this epidemic and to make sure that our people and our economies can return to normality as quickly as possible.

name: Presidente. –
text: The debate is over. Written declarations (Article 171)

name: Magdalena Adamowicz (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Today's discussion on the use of smartphone apps to manage the spread of the pandemic is not only crucial in the context of the gradual lifting of restrictions on freedom of movement in the Union, but also in the context of protecting the privacy of EU citizens.  Mobile applications are developed and already used in some Member States to track people infected or at risk of being infected with the virus. Such applications can play an important and positive role in the process of loosening pandemic restrictions and gradually returning to normality. However, they also have a disproportionate impact on our fundamental rights, such as data protection and privacy. While the protection of human life and public health is of the utmost importance to all of us, both at EU and national level, it should be strongly emphasised that governments and the private sector must not promote the use of unproven technologies with the potential to violate our rights.  The long history of introducing emergency measures in crisis situations shows that, often when surveillance is introduced, it goes too far, does not achieve its objectives and is often prolonged without justification despite the crisis. Mobile tracking programmes, which can undoubtedly be temporary means of mastering a pandemic until the expected vaccine is widespread, must under no circumstances become a permanent part of an expanded surveillance system.

name: Marc Angel (S&D)
text: in writing. – The European Union and the EU Member States must find coordinated common approach to support the gradual lifting of confinement measures. The Group of Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament (S&D) supports joint approaches, but also underlines the importance of privacy and data protection aspects of every possible digital solutions. I believe that every contact tracing app must comply with EU data protection and privacy rules and should be based on anonymised data. They can complement existing manual contact tracing and according to some Member States these applications can help interrupt the transmission chain of the virus, but the use of them must strictly remain voluntary-based and cannot be linked as condition to other rights, such as border crossings, employment or to entering to public institutions.

name: Markus Buchheit (ID)
text: Writing. – Until recently, the crisis we are experiencing has been beyond our imagination. The people of Europe live in fear for their families, their safety and their future. And it is precisely this paralyzing fear that is now becoming a threat itself. For our freedom. For those who live in fear do not ask unpleasant questions. The "Corona App", the latest lazy promise of salvation, is the holy grail for all those who dream the perverse dream of the "glass citizen". It is sold to us as a special measure for special times. But those who claim this are either naive or lying without turning red. Once it is introduced, it will remain, and it will certainly be used for new purposes. Let us look back to 2001. After the 9/11 terrorist attacks, the U.S. government took advantage of the moment to sell its citizens the restrictions on their rights in the form of the Patriot Act as a panacea against terrorism. Today, almost 20 years later, most of these measures remain in force. Any state surveillance that we allow is a Pandora's box. It will be no different this time. I conclude with the words of Benjamin Franklin: "Whoever gives up freedom to gain security will end up losing both."

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. – Digital solutions such as contact tracing applications are essential in the fight against COVID-19, particularly as countries ease lockdown measures. However, strong privacy safeguards must be essential. Thus far the Commission has maintained that contact tracing apps should guarantee privacy, should not store unnecessary personal information including location tracking, should be installed voluntarily, and dismantled post-pandemic. Although these safeguards are essential, they must also be enforced on a Member State level and there must be interoperability between different contact tracing applications. Additionally, the Commission must enforce independent app reviews and audits on a Member State level. These apps must be frequently checked for privacy, transparency, and functional usability concerns, especially as the COVID-19 is still evolving. The Commission should help the Member States assemble a team of cross-sector experts for these reviews. Medical experts should determine that these apps can be effectively integrated into different phases of virus containment. Technical and data experts should consistently guarantee privacy and functionality. Legal experts must continuously develop and provide regulatory framework and legislation updates on data collection and data destruction. Further, this entire process must be extremely transparent so that the public feels comfortable using the apps.

name: Łukasz Kohut (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The right to privacy is one of the fundamental human rights. It is guaranteed by international legal acts, European law and the Polish Constitution – article 47 of the Basic Law explicitly states this.  However, the right to privacy is not an absolute right, as even in the most democratic states it can be restricted for reasons of important public interest. However, these restrictions must be implemented on the basis of generally applicable law and must be necessary and proportionate. This is very important, because any interference with an individual's privacy is an interference with their freedom.  The coronial pandemic has put many governments in the dilemma of whether to control the movement of citizens in the name of controlling the expansion of the pandemic or not to risk interfering with their freedom. Because we know very well that such interference is always a chance to commit abuse. All the more so because current technologies enable large-scale surveillance. Most EU governments have chosen the first option: for example, the Home Quarantine app is used in Poland.  I am not opposed to solutions to monitor the movement of the pandemic. After all, it is about protecting the health and life of the people of the Union. However, I would like to stress strongly that such arrangements must be proportionate and serve precisely monitoring, not surveillance. They must also be consistent at EU level: the protection of the right to privacy should not be less for some and greater for others.

name: Έλενα Κουντουρά (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. – There is no doubt that the effective treatment of COVID-19 is necessary to use digital technology. We'd all like to be safe, knowing that we have an app that will anonymously inform us about potential vectors of the virus. First, however, we must ensure that the data collection practices developed must be safe, effective, transparent, and that they fully meet the criteria of appropriateness and necessity required by the principle of proportionality. But how effective are these applications today? To date, several technical weaknesses remain that must be overcome immediately to ensure their validity. But, even so, the data show that 60-75% of a country's population must use them to be elementaryly effective. In Greece, the vulnerable population, over the age of 50, makes up the majority and does not use smartphones, at 71%. If we take into account that the use of applications takes place on a voluntary basis, the serious risk of the failure of the project becomes even more obvious. But sectors such as tourism need practical solutions now. How will this be done when each EU state uses its own application? If these questions are not answered immediately, I fear that the use of contact tracking and warning applications becomes "too little too late"!

name: Elżbieta Kruk (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. " New technologies and digital services bring not only benefits, but also risks. Benefits when they serve citizens, threats when used for mass surveillance of citizens, violations of privacy and violations of fundamental human rights under the pretext of protecting citizens in times of crisis. There is evidence that crises are being used to introduce observation tools that are maintained after they have been completed and also used for other purposes, such as not only to control the distance between people, but also to control crowds or surveillance of citizens. This can lead to the creation of totalitarian states. In addition, databases can become the target of hackers.  Our privacy and freedom, on the one hand, and security on the other hand are not mutually exclusive, on the contrary, we can only feel safe if our privacy and freedom are maintained and not living in a country that can interfere unrestrictedly with our privacy. The right of the state to observe society as a whole is dangerous for democracy, freedom and civil rights. After all, there is a presumption of innocence. Therefore, the public prosecutor's office and the courts must deal with each case individually. The way to ensure true security is to effectively prosecute individual violations and consistently punish offenders. If we do not remember these threats, new technologies and digital services can bring about the end of human freedom.

name: Eva Maydell (PPE)
text: in writing. – With many countries phasing out of lockdowns, we need a comprehensive and effective strategy to decrease and mitigate the continued threat posed by COVID-19 to our societies. One component of an effective COVID-19 exit strategy is contact tracing apps, as discussed in our plenary debate today. In order for these contact tracing apps to be effective, we need high levels of trust, protection of citizens’ privacy, and cross-border interoperability. How can we ensure trust, privacy, and interoperability? First, contact tracing apps should only be used by public health authorities and be limited to the emergency response to COVID-19. These apps must be consent-based and have the utmost regard for citizens’ privacy. It is worth stressing that contact tracing apps must go hand in hand with other measures, such as social distancing, masks and testing. However, when utilised effectively, and per the above criteria, contact tracing apps can be very beneficial in helping us to learn how to live alongside the virus, until a vaccine or treatment is found.

name: Andżelika Anna Możdżanowska (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. " An effective fight against COVID-19 on all fronts is paramount to ensure that we return to normal life and prevent further economic collapse. The coronavirus contact tracking app should ensure safety when it comes to health and information about EU citizens. Maximum security of sensitive data, decentralisation, interoperability of systems, specific application use time, cooperation of all Member States in the development of the solution are elements through which we will all trust new technologies. Consultation with the medical community and NGOs, industry and business organisations, as well as complete voluntary use, are extremely important.  A great example of fast response, good cooperation and world-class security is the ProteGo Safe application implemented by Poland. It is a fully decentralized solution not related to, for example, the application "Home Quarantine", designed for another group of users and pursuing other purposes. It is constantly tested for cybersecurity, does not use location data, unlike solutions in some EU countries, it does not require your own name, Social Security number, telephone number or other identification data and will only be used to prevent COVID-19 infection. Let us use the good practices of the Member States to minimise interference with the privacy of EU citizens.  We expect such solutions, in line with the GDPR, for all EU citizens to feel safe, willing to use innovative solutions and protect themselves by protecting others.

name: Sandra Pereira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – The EU has recently assumed that the development of a technology aimed at collecting citizens' data via their mobile phones on the pretext of analysing mobility patterns, including the impact of containment measures on the intensity of contacts and the risks of covid-19 spreading. There are some details that are unclear to us, beyond the scope of applicability and concrete objectives. Thus, we are concerned about issues such as: the responsibility for compiling and processing the data; what data will be used and collected; making available and access to them; for what period of time they will be saved; whether all Member States have agreed to the use of such technology; and finally how it is envisaged to ensure the safeguarding of personal data, ensuring full respect for the protection of citizens' data, their privacy, intimacy and confidentiality. Ultimately, the genuine concern of those who install the application cannot be transformed into a mechanism for monitoring and controlling citizens and restricting freedoms. Regardless of whether the installation of these applications is voluntary, no one should be discriminated against for not doing so. We reaffirm that what is fundamental is the investment in a public health service, of quality, universal and free.

name: Christine Schneider (PPE)
text: Writing. – I support the use of "Corona apps" to support an exit from the current restrictions. Social distancing measures can flatten the infection curve, but we need the widespread use of tracing apps so that tracing data can be tracked in the fight against COVID-19 infection chains. It is important that these apps work across European borders and are compatible with each other. And it is especially important that data protection is guaranteed at all times when using tracing apps.

name: Edina Tóth (PPE)
text: in writing. – In response to the COVID-19 pandemic, contact tracing and warning apps can be essential tools to support the gradual lifting of confinement measures. To that end, I warmly welcome the digital initiative of the European Parliament, aiming to develop a common coordinated approach. Whether the contract tracing app is a pan-European system or a decentralised approach, it should, in all circumstances, be reliable, safe and effective. Before launching an app for broadcasting the ‘digital handshake’ of nearby phones, there should be clear guidelines on the protection of personal data and privacy. In particular, I firmly believe COVID19-related health data should be encrypted, i.e. anonymised and solely shared with public health authorities; both are cornerstone for strengthening citizens’ trust in using EU-wide digital tools. Furthermore, whereas ‘digital handshake’ remains decentralised, there should be one app per country - all of which are interoperable - to boost the effectiveness of tracing the circulation of the virus. In addition, the app should be dismantled as soon as they are no longer needed. Finally, in my opinion, an unreasonably complex solution may hinder reaching our common aim, thus we should come up with a solution as simple as possible.

name: Adrián Vázquez Lázara (Renew)
text: in writing. – The coronavirus has returned us all to a Europe that we thought was forgotten: the Europe of borders. Regaining freedom of movement as soon as possible must be a priority, and we cannot afford to waste a single tool at our disposal to achieve this.  Mobile applications for tracing COVID-19 contagion are some of these tools. With proper regulation, and respecting the anonymity and privacy of our data, this technology allows our mobiles to exchange an encrypted code with the people with which we are crossing and, if we have been in contact with a focus of contagion, test ourselves and isolate ourselves quickly. However, the existence of different software models for the development of these applications has called into question their interoperability between European countries, with the consequent risk to freedom of movement and, with it, to key economic sectors, such as tourism in Spain.  We require the Commission and national governments, regardless of the technical model they choose to develop these applications, to ensure their interoperability across Europe.

name: Loránt Vincze (PPE)
text: in writing. – Contact tracing apps are one of the novel digital techniques we can deploy to manage the spread of the pandemic. We should, however, keep in mind that smartphone contact-tracing is just one element of the measures such as social distancing, masks and testing that we must put in place to slow the spread of the virus. There are several preconditions for such apps to be effective. Most importantly, they must be able to rely upon a robust testing and diagnosing infrastructure, otherwise we would not have the data to feed in the network. The second question is how to reach the 60% participation of the local populations in the contact-tracing network that is needed for the app to be effective. While we should strive to reach this figure, the approach we should take is not to make the use of apps mandatory, but to build the trust of people to use the app through solid data-protection. Third, in order to be effective in the whole of the EU, national apps should be inter-operable across borders. Interoperable national systems could be extremely important for relaxing confinement measures, the gradual lifting of border controls and the restoration of freedom of movement.

name: Bettina Vollath (S&D)
text: Writing. – Using tracing applications to contain the pandemic may well be beneficial. Such apps can help us identify more quickly who is infected and who that person was in contact with. This allows us to act more efficiently and break infection chains more quickly. However, one thing must be absolutely clear in the context of such tracing apps: the protection of privacy and fundamental rights is above any benefit that such applications can bring. When I hear politicians in Europe thinking aloud about making use of these applications, I wonder whether some colleagues have forgotten their own data protection regulations. The protection of privacy and one's own data is a fundamental right and must not fall victim to this crisis, especially in view of the sensitive nature of information. Every tracing app should follow the guidelines issued by the Commission and comply with the data protection rules in force – as this House reiterated in a resolution back in April. The fact that this is indeed the case must be ensured by the competent data protection authorities. Only if citizens can rely on their rights to be protected will they also trust and use such applications.
