text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the Council and Commission statements on vaccines and medicines related to COVID-19 (2020/2643(RSP)). I would point out to Members that there are no spontaneous speeches in this debate and that no blue cards are accepted.

name: Nikolina Brnjac
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, on behalf of the Croatian Presidency of the Council, it is my honour to contribute to Parliament’s discussion today on vaccines and therapeutics in the context of the COVID—19 pandemic. This pandemic constitutes an unprecedented challenge for Europe and the world. It has brought huge human losses and suffering, as well as social and economic damage to millions of people. It has put our healthcare systems under exceptional pressure. It has wide-ranging implications for all of us in every part of the European Union. As we gradually start lifting confinement measures, we will have to learn to live with the coronavirus under strict conditions and constant monitoring. Only the development, production and deployment of effective and safe vaccines and treatments will hopefully provide us with a lasting solution to this global health crisis.  Vaccines and treatments will be crucial for Europe, but they will be even more critical for our most vulnerable partners with fragile health systems such as Africa. Our ultimate and common goal, therefore, is to accelerate the development, manufacture and delivery of vaccines and treatments for everyone, everywhere at an affordable price in the shortest possible time.  The EU and its Member States have embarked on a worldwide race to find a safe and effective vaccine and treatments to counter the spread of the coronavirus. Regarding activities at EU level, already on 10 March at their first meeting after the COVID—19 pandemic reached Europe, EU leaders committed to supporting research as part of our common response to the outbreak. The European Parliament has also raised issues relating to the development of vaccines and treatments in its resolution on EU coordinated action to combat the COVID—19 pandemic adopted on 17 April.  On April 7, the Croatian Presidency organised an informal videoconference where ministers responsible for research and innovation showed their determination to coordinate their actions and welcomed ten actions for immediate response to the crisis.  On 7 May, in an informal videoconference organised by the Commission, many Member States supported the idea of preparing a COVID—19 vaccination immunisation plan. To accelerate the coronavirus vaccine, the Commission has launched a dedicated COVID—19 data portal that enables researchers to upload, access and analyse research data. Currently, there are more than 90 vaccines in development around the globe, but only eight are so far subject to clinical trials.  Three candidates for vaccines are receiving support from EU funding through the research programme Horizon 2020. Member States are also investing in several candidates.  Moving to treatments, it is encouraging to note that there are so far more than 40 developers of potential treatments for COVID—19 who have contacted the European Medicines Agency and the Member States for scientific advice. Most of the treatments proposed are medicines currently authorised for other diseases. Clinical trials are currently ongoing to determine their efficiency for the treatment of COVID—19 patients. The EU has allocated resources via Horizon 2020 to Discovery, an EU—wide clinical trial to test treatments involving more than 3 000 European patients. The EU has already committed over EUR 500 million to different research and innovation initiatives, including approximately EUR 48 million to 18 projects on vaccines and treatments via Horizon 2020 research programmes, and EUR 72 million in public funds for a therapeutics and diagnostics innovative medicine initiative with an additional EUR 45 million in expected contributions from the industry.  Additionally, the EU has redirected EUR 150 million from SMEs and start—ups for innovative solutions to tackle the outbreak via the European Innovation Council (EIC) Accelerator programme and up to EUR 80 million to CureVac, a European vaccine developer, by a common Commission aid initiative. In order to respond to the urgency, the European Medicines Agency will speed up its regulatory procedures so that marketing authorisation of safe, effective and high-quality COVID—19 related medicines and vaccines can be guaranteed without unnecessary delay.  Turning now to activities at international level, on 24 April, the WHO launched global cooperation for the accelerated development, production and equitable access to diagnostics, therapeutics and vaccines. In response to this call, on 4 May, the European Union, several Member States and other G20 countries co—hosted the International Coronavirus Global Response Pledging Conference. The initiative has raised EUR 7.4 billion, including EUR 4 billion from the EU and its Member States. This is a very promising and important first step.  There are a number of key challenges. Once new therapies are identified, the challenge will be to scale up production and distribution to make them available to patients throughout the world at an affordable price.  As regards vaccines, the first challenge is the patient’s safety and to produce a vaccine in extremely high quantities, since demand is global.  At the European level, already in December 2018 the Council adopted a recommendation on strengthened cooperation against vaccine—preventable diseases, which has the double aim of reducing inequalities between Member States and increasing security of vaccine supply. EU instruments such as joint procurement could be used in that spirit to help ensure fair distribution and solidarity among all Member States. In order to tackle other important issues, such as securing sufficient and autonomous production capacity in the European Union, fair licensing and fair intellectual property rights conditions, it is necessary to involve all concerned actors, including industry and the public sector.  In this context, I find it very encouraging to see that several manufacturers have agreed to pool their resources. Public authorities, pharmaceutical companies and multilateral organisations must work together to reach the common goal of making vaccines and treatments available to as many as possible.  We will defeat the COVID—19 crisis and we will do it with a shared spirit of European and global solidarity and responsibility.

name: Margaritis Schinas
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, from the very first day of this crisis for us in the Commission, one consideration was evident: no country in the European Union or worldwide can battle this pandemic alone. We need to take bold steps and we need to take them together.  Containment measures have proved efficient so far and have allowed us to diminish the spread of the virus. But they will not eradicate it. For this, we need further action on three areas: first, early diagnosis; second, targeted treatments for the ill; and, third, a vaccine that will ensure immunisation. We will also need all three to be widely accessible and affordable because, as long as the virus exists in the world, no one can be safe.  This is why the European Union is taking the lead in organising a coronavirus global response pledging initiative, which took place on 4 May. The aim was precisely to lead the world effort to develop diagnostics, vaccines and therapeutics against the virus as soon as possible, not only to make it possible to get to these objectives, but also to ensure that they are accessible on a fair and equitable basis once they are discovered. I am delighted to have this opportunity, on behalf of the Commission, to discuss these issues with you in a bit more detail this afternoon.  First, vaccines. On vaccines, there is no doubt that this is the best way to truly exit the pandemic and avoid a resurgence of the disease. However, developing a vaccine is a complicated process that depends on close coordination, financial support and unity. Each of these considerations was evident during the pledging event of 4 May that the European Union led at global level. First, we managed to attain our overall objective with an ambitious level of funding raised. We mobilised EUR 7.4 billion (USD 8 billion) in pledges, of which EUR 5 billion came from Team Europe. The second – and equally important – aspect of this pledging conference was that we sent, as the European Union, a resounding message of unity and solidarity across the world, and we also proved that, in today’s turbulent times, the European Union remains a force for good for the planet.  This was only the beginning. The pledging marathon remains open until 23 May, so I take this opportunity to encourage all of you to engage in helping to find new donors, public or private, and to join forces in this unique worldwide effort.  Here comes the big question: where are we on the vaccines? As the Croatian Presidency has just indicated, the WHO has identified 8 vaccine candidates in clinical evaluation and 94 candidates in pre—clinical evaluation. Three candidates are receiving support from the Commission through our Horizon 2020 programme, and Member States are also investing in several candidates. We need to focus efforts on finding the most promising solutions. That’s why the Commission has proposed that an EU—wide network for clinical trials be set up. Such a network will ensure a critical mass of data from patients, help to identify the most promising vaccine candidates or therapeutics, and swiftly move them into the most appropriate clinical trials. Once developed, of course, a vaccine would need to pass a rigorous approval process, and we in the Commission will work very closely with the European Medicines Agency to ensure that this process moves as swiftly and as quickly as possible without, however, compromising on safety and efficacy.  Producing the vaccine is only half of the battle ahead of us. We should also ensure fair, widespread and equitable access to the vaccine as early as possible, not only to all Europeans, but also to the rest of the world. There are many tools that we could use to achieve this – from public—private partnerships to increased manufacturing capacity, to advance purchase agreements to ensure production. The Commission is currently in intensive discussions with both our Member States and vaccine producers to identify clearly how we can best support Member States in the purchase and deployment of vaccines. All options are on the table and we are not excluding any of them. Last week, health ministers discussed the possibility of a uniform COVID-19 immunisation strategy throughout the European Union. This would also help us to maximise access to the vaccine when it becomes available and I look forward to hearing your thoughts on these approaches this afternoon. Let me now turn to therapeutics. The Commission has reacted efficiently to support Member States in this regard. I don’t want to beautify the situation. We all know that the early stage of the crisis was not an example of optimal coordination. Many measures were taken rapidly under pressure at national level without the necessary coordination. But, once this first stage went through and our Member States saw the added value of cooperation and the interdependence that binds them together as the European Union, with the help of the Commission, we reacted efficiently to support them. Let me recall some of these actions.  Since day one, we have coordinated closely with all important actors – the European Medicines Agency, the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control (ECDC), the national agencies, industry – to avoid or tackle bottlenecks, to better anticipate future shortages and to assist in the adaptation of production. In parallel, we have issued concrete guidance on the rational supply of medicines, regulatory flexibility and clinical trials to avoid unavailability of treatments. We have activated the rescEU stockpile of medical equipment, including therapeutics and vaccines, and we have established a COVID clearing house mechanism that facilitates the matching of the needs for medical equipment with available supplies.  Thankfully, the situation is now beginning to stabilise in the EU, but we must also continue working on the supply side. With this in mind, we are supporting a dedicated industry cooperation project to increase the supply of critical intensive care unit medicines. Parallel to that, the European Medicines Agency and the Commission have put in place a mechanism to support the rapid development and authorisation of new COVID-19 medicines and vaccines and, as we speak, we are currently preparing a joint procurement for such intensive care unit (ICU) medicines. Let me conclude by saying that today we are, of course, discussing the short term, which is saving lives and winning the battle with the virus on the medical side, but I would like to finish with a few words about the medium and long term. The pandemic has revealed and amplified important issues with our supply chain for medicinal products. I’m very aware of how dependent we are on important pharmaceutical products or ingredients. So we need to come together quickly and identify solutions to the three emerging weaknesses from the crisis: how to strengthen our coordination mechanisms and supply chains, how to boost our preparedness, and how to improve our society’s overall strategic resilience. The Commission is preparing a new pharmaceutical strategy that will take account of the lessons learned during the pandemic and make the EU’s pharmaceutical system future proof and crisis resistant. Yesterday, President von der Leyen had the opportunity to give you a bit more detail about our very intensive work on the recovery initiative, which is to be expected in the next few days. I would say that part of building this resilience for cohesive and resistant European societies passed from a very rigorous health programme that would bridge this asymmetry between what Europeans expect from Europe in the area of public health and what Europe has in terms of legal competence to face up to this challenge.  Commissioner Kyriakides and I will look forward to working very closely with this House on this endeavour. But first, I am keen to hear your thoughts on the challenges and solutions and I am very willing to take them on board and report back to you at my earliest convenience.  (Applause)

name: Peter Liese
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which We all yearn for normality. Not only the economy suffers from the lockdown, but also many people personally. But the coronavirus is still among us, and it is still very dangerous. That is why we must be careful, careful, so that there is no second wave. And we also need to use digital solutions.  I was a little annoyed and disappointed that Commissioner Reynders actually just listed the concerns this morning. We have to be offensive. And we have to look to Italy, Spain, France and Belgium, to the countries that have suffered the most from the crisis. Strangely enough, hardly anyone complains about the lockdown. In my country, Germany, one gets the impression that there is a great deal of reason to complain, even though we have got through much better. I shout to my fellow citizens: "Stop lamenting me, and show solidarity with those who have been hit much harder!" The final solution, of course, comes with only one drug or a vaccine. Personally, after many discussions with experts, I am personally optimistic that we will get a drug and/or vaccine much faster than under normal circumstances. The conference held by the European Commission last Monday was a clear sign of cooperation and dialogue.  Unfortunately, however, we also need a Plan B. The United States did not attend the conference at government level, and that is why we should continue to engage in dialogue, but we should also be prepared, for example, to issue compulsory licences in Europe in a coordinated manner or to use trade policy instruments. When Donald Trump threatened to impose tariffs on European cars, Jean-Claude Juncker went to the White House and made a counter-threat. And the health of our citizens must be at least as important to us as the car industry. Ursula von der Leyen says: "We must speak the language of power." This also applies to this issue.

name: Tiemo Wölken
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done. If the PPE-DE is already talking about compulsory licences, then there really is a big problem to be solved – no, Peter is very right about many things.  A vaccine to treat and combat this pandemic is currently being intensively sought all over the world. This morning, Commissioner, Mr. Efsovic, spoke of solidarity. He said that the prosperity of a country should not determine whether the people there can live without this virus. He is right.  And yet today we read in the media that the CEO of a French health company says: If we have developed a vaccine, it will go first to the Americans. I wonder whether the money we, as Europeans, put into research and development is seen as a gift, rather than something to which a company is entitled. This is not solidarity, it is capitalism with people's lives. We cannot accept that.  That is why we clearly need equal access to a vaccine in the European Union and worldwide. I am glad that my group has developed a plan for a European Health Union, which shows that we Europeans have realised that we have too much dependence on non-European countries in the area of health care – and the next crisis will come. We are not talking about antimicrobial resistance (AMR) at the moment. In this respect, we need to do much more, and in this respect I look forward to working together.

name: Véronique Trillet-Lenoir
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. Madam President, health is a common good, a public good, a global good, a European good. We collectively defend ourselves, during this epidemic, by our reasonable and respectful behaviours, as in this Chamber. We welcome the European Commission's research funding efforts to develop treatments, vaccines and tests. The European Parliament voted overwhelmingly, in its april resolution, on a European health response mechanism and we have collectively called for the strengthening of health agencies, closer cooperation between researchers and the restoration of our European sovereignty. Let us not allow third countries to make us dependent on their research and production of medicines. Let's not let GAFAM take over our patients' medical data. Let's not let the healthcare industry, Sanofi or others, bid with human lives and confiscate chances of recovery in the name of profit. Let's negotiate, together, with them the prices of the drugs. I agree with you, Commissioner, let us make the European Medicines Agency the linchpin of coordinated clinical studies. We will prevent them from competing with each other. Let's make the Agency for Disease Control and Prevention the heart of a network of European laboratories of excellence in public-private partnership. We can do this if we are determined, united and united Europeans, and if we include a specific health programme in the multi-year financial contract.

name: Silvia Sardone
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Europe is making serious mistakes on the coronavirus health emergency. There has been a lack of solidarity between European countries - you will all remember the failure to send respirators and masks to the countries most affected, such as Italy, for example - each country acted differently on tampons and the counting of deaths and then also on treatment, medicines and vaccines: Europe was totally absent. But today I want to talk to you about the treatment with hyperimmune plasma, a simple cure that has existed in medicine for almost a century, now tested on Covid-19 in Mantua and Pavia, Italy, with excellent results. Let me give you some figures: in very serious patients in intensive care, mortality has increased from 15 % to 6 %, and in Mantua mortality is even reduced to zero. Think that in the United States, 116 universities are already experimenting. Let's talk about the costs: antiviral drugs cost 4, 5 or 6 times more than a simple plasma bag.  Yet both the Italian Government and you in Europe do not seem particularly interested in this. How come? Well it doesn't have behind the multinational drug companies, there are no big investments and the strong powers of the industry, there are no big contracts and millionaire earnings. Perhaps then it is better for some to focus on something else. It's a mistake. We call for Europe to support this therapy economically while waiting for a vaccine and to encourage the creation of dedicated plasma banks in the various European countries.

name: Petra De Sutter
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, I first want to congratulate the Commission on the successful pledging conference of last week. A lot of public money indeed has been pledged now to secure funding for the development of vaccines, diagnostics and therapeutics. This money, however, should not come as a blank cheque to the pharmaceutical industry. Policymakers should take the necessary measures to make sure that vaccines and therapeutics will be accessible to all. First, I believe that the EU should support the W8 in setting up a transparent and inclusive governance structure that will decide on the development, production and equitable distribution of future vaccines and therapeutics globally. All relevant stakeholders, including civil society and the global south, should be represented in this governance structure. Second, the health of our citizens should not only depend on the goodwill, as we understood it, of the pharmaceutical sector – we cannot rely on voluntary measures only. If needed, EU Member States should be able to make use of compulsory licensing. While we Greens have always been supporting this, I was happy to hear that colleagues of other political groups like Mr Liese just now are also aboard for this idea. But to facilitate the use of compulsory licensing, it’s also crucial that the EU urgently makes its legislation on data and market exclusivity more flexible. I invite us all to collaborate on this. Colleagues, let us use this health crisis to fundamentally improve our pharmaceutical system in safeguarding public health over profit maximisation. If not now, then when?

name: Joanna Kopcińska
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab I fully support the Commission's global response to the coronavirus event, which has registered EUR 7.4 billion in donations from donors around the world. The Visegrad Group, of which Poland is a part, has allocated EUR 3 million to vaccines and medicines against the virus as part of this initiative.  When new treatments and vaccines are ready for market, the European Structural and Investment Funds should play a key role in increasing production capacity with particular care and ensuring a fair and appropriate allocation for each Member State. Nevertheless, the development of the vaccine entails significant costs and a high risk of failure. It will take a long time to develop safe and effective vaccines that will be authorised and we must be aware that there are no easy and quick solutions in this process. Finding a vaccine quickly is important, but it is more important that it is effective and safe for patients. In the case of rapid development of the vaccine, all side effects may not be known, so the question of liability requires a resolution.  In conclusion, I would like to ask the Commission about the measures it is planning to ensure universal access to vaccine research results, to find a way to speed up clinical trials, and to address the issue of liability once vaccines have been purchased and used.

name: Marc Botenga
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, I’ve got a question that I don’t want you to answer. That question is, how much are you willing to pay to save your life? And yet, unfortunately, that question is still very much used by many pharmaceutical companies to decide on the price of a treatment or a vaccine. That is what explains why a Belgian family had to pay EUR 1.9 million euros for a life-saving treatment to Novartis. That also explains why the CEO of Sanofi dares to threaten to give the vaccine first to the United States. And that explains why today, Belgian health authorities fear that the vaccine will not be available to all. So that is why it is so, so important for us to make sure that no pharmaceutical company gets an exclusive right on the coming treatment or vaccine. And granted, the European Union has, by and large, talked the talk, and that is important. We’ve spoken about a common public good that will not belong to anybody. However, when we talk the talk, you should also walk the walk, because otherwise it’s just hypocrisy. And that is why I was so surprised and, indeed, disappointed to read on the website of the Commission that you were not going to touch the intellectual property rights. Now for me, it’s very, very clear. We raised 7.4 billion. That 7.4 billion should not serve the private profits of pharmaceutical companies. Let me be clear: in a pandemic, patents have no place. We have a right to a cure and we have a right to a people’s vaccine.

name: Piernicola Pedicini (NI).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that it is worth remembering that vaccines are a health solution that serves a prevention policy, they are drugs that are used for healthy people, not for the sick, and therefore for the majority of the population. So it is not enough that they are effective but they must be absolutely safe, free of side effects and created and distributed in large quantities for the whole population. Their development therefore takes a very long time for research, production and distribution and, therefore, they are not a solution to the immediate urgency that we have at the moment. At the moment we are in the middle of a pandemic crisis and there are thousands of people dying in the European Union.  Was $7.4 billion raised? Very well, then, most of this money must be used for therapies that have proved their effectiveness, and I am thinking in particular of hyperimmune plasma, which has just been mentioned and which has shown that 100 % of patients can be treated in hospitals in Pavia and Mantua. Unfortunately, this is happening with the obstacle, with the resistance of the pharmaceutical industry, which clearly has no interest in this therapeutic solution.  Mr President, this is a scandal! We have the solution at hand, we can cure the people who are going to die and we can save our economy with this solution, but we absolutely must prevent pharmaceutical companies from doing their private interest. Instead, we must safeguard the general interest.

name: Dolors Montserrat (PPE).
text: – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, this May, forty years ago, the world broke free from smallpox thanks to another global ten-year effort and more than 500 million vaccines.  COVID is the first crisis in globalization, it has gone around the world in just 115 days and this virus has shown us our fragility. Therefore, we need a vaccine and treatment to provide a definitive solution to this pandemic.  I would like to applaud the Commission's leadership in achieving more than EUR 7 billion to finance the development of the COVID vaccine. It is the largest public-private, global and health collaboration project.  It's time to be brave, but also generous. We can't allow price or country wars or war between the public and the private. We have to do it together and we must remove any barriers to access to vaccines, which must be available to everyone in every corner of the world.  The relocation of the production of a strategic sector such as the healthcare sector has paid very expensive, also in Spain. We must bet on health re-industrialization and research in Europe, and Europe differs from the United States and China by having the best national public and universal health systems in the world. This is our great added value.  This crisis therefore gives us the opportunity to review and strengthen the European health system, so that it is more resilient; and the European Union must have more health competences to quickly and efficiently coordinate a single European health system.  We have to work for the European health union.

name: Javi López (S&D).
text: – Madam President, today the European Parliament is calling on the Member States and institutions of the European Union to coordinate, to work together to seek a vaccine and effective treatment to deal with coronavirus. And we want to join forces not only between European states and institutions, we want to join forces between the private sector and the public sector.  Parliament also sets an example of the European Commission's initiative of the International Donor Conference , more than EUR 7.4 billion collected jointly. But today Parliament is not only doing this. Today Parliament also sends a strong message about the need for a future vaccine with universal, free, fair, equal access and fast access to all corners of Europe. This can also be made possible by the joint procurement mechanism. Thirdly, the European Parliament today also wants the European Union in the future to lead this universal and free access to a future vaccine globally. It's also a time to make warnings about this logic—which we see in some cases—of geopolitical competition to find the vaccine or what the source vaccine can be like also of inequalities. We want to cooperate in a world where some want to compete. Because in the face of coronavirus there is no competition possible for something that affects the whole of humanity and that has jeopardized the way of life of all corners of our planet.

name: Frédérique Ries (Renew).
text: Madam President, many things have already been said, crucial, including our newfound sovereignty over medicines in Europe, our unpreparedness and lack of vision, so I come directly to the theme of our debate: treatments and vaccines. To begin with, Discovery, we haven't talked much about it yet. Discovery, this trial which was to test four tracks, four arms of drugs, launched on 22 March in horn and cry, in principle for 3,200 European patients and which is now de facto shrunk to, I believe, 700 French patients and only one Luxembourg patient, according to my information. I would like to know the reasons for this disaffection and I use an understatement. Some of the researchers I spoke to told me about European criteria that are too stringent for testing, including high prices. I find it quite distressing to see local Member States turning instead to Solidarity, the parallel study launched by WHO. In terms of vaccines, 157 projects according to the London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine, 11 of which are already in clinical trials. A question arises, it is crucial: what do we do if it is discovered in the United States, China or elsewhere? I have listened to your explanations, Commissioner, I am also reading the press, there are denials, but there are great manoeuvres between the big labs and the major powers, can you reassure the Europeans about access and availability?

name: Herve Juvin (ID).
text: Madam President, we agree with the allocation of extensive resources for pharmaceutical and medical research. However, we are concerned about the accelerated privatization of health and life being built by a number of major global oligopolies. That is why we draw the Commission's attention to the fact that it is necessary to fund independent research, academic or public, in the face of the concentration of research in the hands of major pharmaceutical manufacturers. We draw the Commission's attention to the need to ensure a pricing model that will promote the relocation and autonomy of our pharmaceutical and medical industries and ensure access to the common good of health for all. Finally, we warn the Commission against the excesses of the patentability of life, which is in the process of insuring undue rents for industrialists capable of sterilizing research, capable of excluding from the scope of prescriptions recognised medicines, used for decades, and which, finally, are in the process, thanks to the pandemic, to ensure clearly undue benefits to the global pharmaceutical oligopoly.

name: Anna Cavazzini (Verts/ALE).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Access to medicine saves lives. Do we want only those who can afford corona vaccine and medicine to have access to it – here in Europe and around the world? Do we want African states not to be able to manufacture their own ventilators because they violate patent law? No, ladies and gentlemen, we cannot want that! The EU must ensure that everyone everywhere has access to vital technology, medicine and a future vaccine.  In order to ensure that this does not just remain an empty formula, very concrete steps are necessary. EU Member States must guarantee public access to medicine and vaccines for all through compulsory licences. A lot of colleagues have already mentioned this today. The EU must take advantage of the flexibility in commercial law and make it possible for medicine produced under compulsory licences to be imported and traded worldwide. To do this, we need a clear and unclear statement from the Commission, Mr Schinas.  Ladies and gentlemen, we are in this together. Let us send a strong signal from the House today that we are looking at the whole of society and the whole world – and not just those who can afford it!

name: Helmut Geuking (ECR).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her First of all, I would like to stress that, even if the Commission says that we must become resilient to crises, there will never be any resistance to crisis. It is not the first pandemic we are experiencing, nor will it be the last pandemic we are experiencing.  However, I would like to stress that I am very satisfied and i think it is very positive that we now have 123 vaccination projects worldwide, which are already in a testing phase, where we would otherwise be in ten or eleven years' time. In other words, these procedures have been greatly shortened, and that gives hope that next year we will probably have the first vaccine in the world to help people directly.  Yes, it must be our task here in the European Parliament to define framework conditions in this regard: who gets the vaccine, when, at what time, at what price? It goes without saying that every person – this is part of the public interest – must have access to it worldwide and, as the previous speaker is quite right, of course. We need to create a framework: where do we start, where do we stop and how quickly can we produce? In addition, we need to bring production facilities to Europe, especially in the pharmaceutical sector.  Health policy is not a European policy, and it is time for us to make this a European policy. To this end, 21 MePs have now virtually signed a manifesto, who now want to work together across the political groups in the interests of the citizens and people of Europe in order to advance health policy across Europe. I am very happy and very proud of this and I say to the honourable Members: thank you very much for taking part in this, and we will continue to fill that with life. I would ask the Commission to create an institution here in Europe that does justice to this.

name: Mick Wallace (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, we’re talking about addressing symptoms and not causes. The way we produce meat today, with thousands of genetically identical chickens and pigs stuck in massive factories – natural selection, an ecosystem service that provides real-time disease protection, is more, now, effectively a thing of the past. If we do not address industrialised livestock production, we are sure to have bigger and more lethal epidemics than this one. And we cannot win the fight against COVID-19 and future infectious diseases unless we properly fund a public sector that values public health over profit. A health service should not be a business opportunity for big pharma in a health crisis. The chief executive of the French pharmaceutical giant Sanofi said yesterday that they can deliver a vaccine to the Americans, who want to get it first, because they get more funding. This is a company that’s subsidised by the French people. This is a company that distributed EUR 4 billion to its shareholders during the pandemic. The COVID-19 global response framework was announced on 4 May. What conditions will be attached to the fund? At the very least, public investment in a COVID-19 vaccine and the therapeutic development should come with hard conditionalities attached, including real equitable public access, non-exclusive licensing, and an affordable pricing model. But even attaching these conditionalities would not deal with the root of the problem. We need to de-commodify vaccines and therapeutics. We should nationalise pharmaceutical companies, and we should do it now.

name: Antoni Comín i Oliveres (NI).
text: Madam President, governments, companies, scientific committees, everyone is in the race to develop a vaccine against COVID-19 as soon as possible. But the important thing is not only to do everything now to accelerate this development, it is also to ask whether certain things have not been that would have allowed us to significantly shorten the search time. An example: previous research for SARS and MERS vaccines was discontinued during the first phase. If Phases 2 and 3 had been completed, some of the work to discover the COVID-19 vaccine would have already been done today and we would have saved a vital amount of time. Is there useful research on future health threats that are not being carried out today because of a lack of commercial interest, because in this case, the duty of public institutions is to provide the means and resources for this research to be carried out. Let us learn from this health crisis, anticipate, do everything possible to protect the health of the citizens we represent.

name: Ismail Ertug (S&D).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, yesterday we thanked the heroes – the doctors and nurses, the truck drivers and the parents – but colleagues, I just want to ask us all: to what extent do we protect the healthcare workers in the European Union? Is the level of health care enough? This is an issue I want to raise with the Member States as well. We have to raise this issue, and I urge the Commission to come up with a directive where we deal with the level of the healthcare workers as well. And I want to say, I prefer to bite the bullet of social distancing on the beach rather than see people suffering from this crisis.

name: Andreas Glück (Renew).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. The European Union plays a leading role in the research into vaccines and therapeutics.  Firstly, these efforts must continue in the future.  Secondly, the authorisation of medicines must be able to happen more quickly. We do not want compromises on patient safety here, but we must ensure that medicines reach patients more quickly.  Thirdly, even with conventional medicines, we only have two, perhaps three, production lines worldwide. Here it is unrealistic for us to get all production back to Europe, but we at least need diversification in production.  Incidentally – and I would now like to comment briefly on my colleague from the PPE, Mr Liese – that our fundamental freedoms are being restricted shows that the good that the European Union brings cannot be taken for granted. We have to work for it every day. What is important to me is that those who restrict fundamental freedoms must argue and that the burden of proof does not lie with those who want to live fundamental freedoms. Each EU Member State is too small to play an economically important role in the world. And every EU Member State is too small to make a proper contribution to solving the Corona problem.

name: Nicolaus Fest (ID).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Commissioner Schinas has pointed out how efficiently and, of course, in toto, the EU has responded to the Corona crisis. Like all of his statements, this claim lies somewhere between self-deception, self-overestimation and fake news. A proper parliament would not let him go through this either. It would talk about the complete lack of medical preparation within the EU for the Corona crisis, it would talk about the complete lack of coordination between the EU countries in the fight against the Corona pandemic, and, above all, a proper Parliament would talk about the total failure of people like Mr Schinas and Mrs von der Leyen and the entire Commission. And a proper President of Parliament would also put these issues on the agenda and not talk about Poland, Hungary or, well, vaccines. But we do not have a proper Parliament, and unfortunately we do not have a proper President of Parliament either.

name: Pär Holmgren (Verts/ALE).
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for It is, of course, incredibly important now that we get a safe vaccine. We know that it will take time, probably many years, and also that there will be major costs for research, manufacturing and even dissemination. Most of these costs are expected to be covered by government funding to fund research by large multinationals. This money comes without sufficiently clear conditions and requirements, for example in the case of intellectual property rights. The EU has promised to contribute SEK 10 billion. That's good. But firstly, we cannot more or less give away SEK 10 billion without ensuring fair access to both patents and vaccines. If the world is now to jointly fund the development of a vaccine, then the world should also have free access to patents for the licensing of vaccines. And secondly, the precautionary principle applies – we must not make the same mistakes as when we stressed out a vaccine against swine flu, and in Sweden alone 500 people suffered from it.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the whole world is waiting for the vaccine: but let us think about what happened with AIDS, the times it took to try to have it, and we still do not have it. So we have to learn from mistakes, we have to learn from what happened. Europe has found itself totally unprepared to deal with this pandemic. As it advanced in China, Europe discovered that it had no factories producing masks, because the work around those masks was not profitable and it was worth producing in China, and then found that it did not have gloves, which are produced only in Taiwan or Malaysia. And again he found that the production of alcohol was contingent. A series of errors that made us find totally uncovered. This virus was terrible, it completely ripped apart our lives. You see, for those who are Christian and Catholic, like me, it is a terrible experience not to be able to say goodbye to a loved one personally, but to have to say it by videoconference. We are therefore aware that this virus must be combated, and it must be combated with the solidarity that Europe must regain and, above all, realizing that there can be neither north nor south, but Europe must be united and united.

name: Christel Schaldemose (S&D).
text: Madam President! Thank you for that, and also thank you for this discussion and presentation by the Commission of the actions that have been taken at this stage. I think we've learned a whole lot from the corona crisis. First of all, it is extremely important that we work together to learn more about this disease, and also work together to find out how we cure and how we vaccinate. We've been told a lot about that, and that's really good. In addition, however, I also believe that it is important that the next step is handled in such a way that we learn from the fact that we must not be dependent on the world outside the European Union. We simply need to ensure that we also produce protective equipment at European level, produce important medicines and, of course, also produce the vaccine when it is ready at some point. We must do this by working together, we are funding it together and coordinating it much better across the Member States than we have done up to the corona crisis. So the signal is that we will only solve this together if we work together, but also protect ourselves in Europe together.

name: Margaritis Schinas
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, thank you for this very useful debate. I identified two families of issues from your statements. One – let’s call it the quest for resilience – and the other one is what happens once we have the vaccine? How do we make sure that we avoid the problems that we saw in the early stage about access to the distribution of personal protective equipment?  Let me start on the quest for resilience. There is no doubt whatsoever that Europe has to draw the lessons of this pandemic. It’s evident, it’s written on the wall. This is something that society will impose on all policy-making at all levels. As far as the quest for resilience at the EU level is concerned, let me repeat what I said earlier. We have to bridge this asymmetry of expectations between what Europeans want from Europe in areas where Europe has nothing in terms of legal competence. This is a major issue. This contaminates public opinion and projects Europe in a negative light. I really hope that this will be, together with my colleagues, one of our main lines of action in the months and years to come. Also on the quest for resilience, we have to make sure that the recovery initiative sheds light and reinforces a self-standing health problem that is able to perform not only under regular, normal circumstances, but is also designed to face up to major sanitary crises and pandemics. This is also a major challenge in front of us. Finally, many of you also raised the issues of production, back to the EU, pricing, strategical autonomy, the place of Europe in the world and geopolitics. When it comes to pharmaceuticals and all these questions, I want to assure that they will be addressed in our pharmaceutical strategy communication, which I will be presenting to you, together with Commissioner Kyriakides, later this year. Let me now come to – and finish –the other cluster of issues of concern to you, which is what happens once we have the vaccine, how we make sure that access is fair, equitable and widespread distribution is available to all Europeans and the rest of the world. I think there are three options for us, a three—point strategy that will allow us to act effectively in this respect. First, we need to ensure immediate access to vaccine supplies. For this, we do have instruments to be deployed, namely we can create an EU stockpile of vaccines, serving as an immediate response through the European Union Civil Protection Mechanism, we can organise an EU joint procurement scheme, which will be secure purchase commitments in a stable framework, and the Commission could also procure directly, on behalf of Member States, vaccines making use of the Emergency Support Instrument. This was about immediate actions. Second, regarding secure production, we are already in close contact with industry and we are exploring together with them concrete measures such as public-private partnerships to increase manufacturing capacity or to advance purchase agreements to ensure production. Thirdly, delivery. In the beginning we might need some prioritisation. This is precisely the objective of the European immunisation strategy that I was referring to in my opening statement. Such an immunisation strategy could set priority strands for certain segments of the population, but we will also need to ensure access worldwide because, as long as the virus exists, no one is safe. This is again precisely the purpose of our global leadership in the framework of the pledging conference that should not end on 23 May, when we have this critical mass of financing to speed up the production of vaccines. But we will also have a role, after 23 May, to make sure that the rest of the world and especially those parts of the world that have more vulnerable health systems, like Africa or Latin America, will not be left out of this development.

name: Nikolina Brnjac
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, honourable Members, I wish to thank you for this important debate. We have one common goal around the world and that is to defeat the virus. As the Commissioner said, no country is able to defeat the COVID-19 pandemic alone. There is only one way to defeat it, namely with a combination of prevention through vaccination and treatment of people who have fallen ill. Unfortunately, we still have to wait for treatments and vaccines to be found. The European Union has mobilised important resources and it is fully involved in a coordinated global effort to develop, produce and employ vaccines and treatments for all. A positive dynamic has developed with the launching of the Coronavirus Global Response Pledging effort. The European Union is fully committed to support Member States’ efforts within and outside the Union. We know that we can now count on the cooperation of all EU institutions in this endeavour. In particular, we hope we can coordinate with the European Parliament. Until an efficient, accessible, affordable vaccine is developed, it is important that we continue respecting the epidemiological measures to protect all our loved ones.

name: Cristian-Silviu Buşoi (PPE)
text: in writing. – COVID-19 has proven one more time that vaccination represents one of the most powerful and cost-effective public health measure. The entire world is currently waiting for the development and deployment of a vaccine anti COVID-19, in order to return to the daily routine before the pandemic. We have at the moment more than 100 COVID19 vaccine development projects worldwide, 8 of them are already in clinical trial phase, of which 3 are supported by Horizon 2020. Once developed, it is important to ensure swift authorisation by our trusted partner, the European Medicine Agency and work in close collaboration with European pharma sector to provide the necessary production capacity. With great concern, I want to remind you that EU is the region of the world with the lowest confidence in the safety and effectiveness of vaccines. One of the strongest drivers for vaccine hesitancy are misunderstandings about the benefits and risks of vaccines, the severity of vaccine preventable infectious diseases and the fear of potential side effects derived from misleading information. Consequently, I stress the ongoing need to reinforce our actions, together with the Commission, Member States, EMA and ECDC to tackle vaccine hesitancy, improve vaccination coverage, promote sustainable vaccination policies, and contribute eventually to European and global health.

name: Margarita de la Pisa Carrión (ECR)
text: in writing. – This is not the first time we have faced shortages of goods internationally: today it is medicines, tomorrow it will be the vaccine. We know that fair distribution of them will not only ensure health, it can also prevent dramatic friction between countries. Something that has unfortunately already happened within the EU, called this institution into question. It is time to join forces, of agreements between countries. We call on the Commission to assume its role of coordinating the Member States, prioritizing the essentials and forgetting ideological proclamations that only materialize grudges and accentuate division. We must anticipate health problems, we need a fair distribution based on patient needs, real demand, not storage forecasts. In the face of scarcity, give priority to those most in need. When the vaccine arrives, clarity in this regard will be essential. We ask the ECDC to share information on the situation in each country: test results, treatment protocols, conclusions... Information essential to be able to plan production, guide the industry towards a possible regrowthe, and that improvisation does not allow an unfair distribution of the most effective medicines or the highly expected vaccine.

name: Cindy Franssen (PPE)
text: Written. – Despite the fact that more and more Member States are fortunately able to implement a gradual relaxation of corona measures, it is also becoming increasingly clear that a treatment or vaccine against the virus remains indispensable. The European Union is rightly at the forefront of international cooperation in the search for this vaccine. This is witnessed, among other things, in the successful donor conference on 4 May, which raised EUR 7.4 billion worldwide. Further cooperation across borders will be needed. However, if a vaccine or treatment is found, it will also be essential to ensure equal access for all citizens. We must not allow the large private companies to make profiteering through patents with a vaccine that the whole world craves, and for which billions of euros have been used in public research funds. Research funded by public funds should also remain available in the public domain. The vaccine must be safe, affordable and universally accessible. For me, this is clear and clear, it is our social duty. Every citizen, in the EU and beyond, has the right to equal access. This can only be done through international cooperation, with countries, companies, NGOs, universities and other research institutions.

name: András Gyürk (PPE)
text: Writing. – The spread of the coronavirus epidemic appears to be slowing down thanks to the sacrifice of European citizens and appropriate measures taken by member state governments. However, in order to definitively defeat pandemic, a scientific breakthrough in the development of targeted vaccination and therapy is also needed. It is important that vaccines and treatments are universally available, because we can only overcome this crisis together. Cooperation is needed at both EU and global level to find the right vaccine. I consider the 'Global Action against the Coronavirus' donor event initiated by the Commission to be an important step, with the €7.4 billion raised as a solid basis for funding relevant research.  However, further and greater support is needed to improve the results of EU research and development. Similar thinking and action are needed to develop targeted therapy. I welcome the fact that the first round of applications for the innovative medicines initiative has been successfully completed. Further financial means should be used to support public and private expertise and resources in the fight against the virus. Finally, it is also worth taking into account good practices in the Member States. Such a good example Hungary, which can save lives through innovative plasma treatment and drug therapy developed by a national scientific consortium. In order to ensure general access to the vaccine, Hungary the establishment of the National Vaccine Factory.

name: César Luena (S&D)
text: in writing. – The development of new vaccines and therapies for COVID-19 disease is critical for Europe and also for its most vulnerable partners such as Africa, as no country can overcome this pandemic individually. International cooperation has added value and allows to tackle blockades and anticipate possible shortages of medicines and products. Globally, its development is accelerating and research and innovation is being supported. We need global coordinated action to achieve innovative actions and launch a message of unity and solidarity.  There are currently eight vaccines in human clinical trials, three of which receive European funding through Horizon 2020. The European Medicines Agency has also scaled its actions against this pandemic, coordinating a European network for clinical trials, providing free scientific advice and combining data on treatments that, although requiring further trials, have received a lot of publicity such as hydroxychloroquine and remdesivir.  In addition, once new treatments and vaccines are developed, we need fast, equal access, at fair prices, and accessible worldwide, for which the joint procurement mechanism put in place by the EU will become particularly relevant and strengthened, involving all responsible parties.

name: Cristina Maestre Martín De Almagro (S&D)
text: in writing. – Since the onset of the health crisis, it has become clear that no country can fight the pandemic alone. Containment measures have been shown to be effective so far in decreasing the spread of the virus, but will not eradicate it. This requires additional coordinated action in three areas: early diagnosis; specific treatments for the sick; and a vaccine that ensures immunization.  The work of EU states and institutions needs to be coordinated to seek effective vaccine and treatment to tackle coronavirus. We must also involve the private sector and the public sector. The International Donor Conference organized by the Commission was a good example, with more than EUR 7.4 billion raised.  It is necessary to send a strong message about the need for a future vaccine with universal, free, fair, equal and fast access. At European level, the joint procurement mechanism is the tool to ensure this.  Finally, the EU must lead this universal and free access to future vaccines and treatments globally. The vaccine cannot be a new source of inequality, nor should it be used as an instrument of geopolitical competition. It is necessary to cooperate, where some want to compete.
